Initially, I heard many good things about this film and so, had high expectations of the film, especially after watching the other great films of the saga.I was very disappointed after I watched it. It lacked any action, and the action it did have was either boring or sloppy. The battle of hoth was too slow paced and very predictable. The battle between Luke and Vader was lame and sloppy compared to awesome prequels battles.Honestly, if the film was brought into the 21st century with better graphics, audio and cinematography it would make the film a lot better.Honestly, give me one reason why people find this film the 'best' in the saga?!
reviews.heading: Overrated and boring

reviews.content: The Empire strikes back is a complex movie to review. On the one hand, in terms of plot development and pacing it feels like a step back from A New Hope. Luke goes to train with Yoda, while his friends evade a Star Destroyer through the power of plot armor. Eventually he goes to save his friends.However, it does a few things exceptionally well:1. Expand the world building of the original film. A New Hope was largely a fairy tale story which could stand on its own. But Empire Strikes back grounds it in a believable universe. The death star is gone, but that barely made a dent in the power of the Empire. The nature of the force is expanded on. The emperor is introduced. Darth Vader isnt just some random bad guy anymore.2. Subverting expectations done right. Structurally, the Empire Strikes back is kind of an odd movie, and its even more unique in that it ends on a pretty dark note. Luke going to save his friends doesn't really work at all. He instead gets his hand chopped off, almost dies and needs their help. But this subversion doesn't just come out of nowhere like a The Last Jedi gotcha, it actually makes sense.3. The plot twist at the end is so well known that people dont really factor it in when reviewing the story 40 years later. But keeping it in mind, this really would be a shocking moment to anyone watching it the first time.Also, with a better director at the helm, Empire Strikes back has better dialogue (slightly, its still not great), better acting, and better cinematography. John Williams even steps it up a notch with the music.Overall, the somewhat weak plot development (it spends far too much time in asteroid fields, a cheesy romance, and training montages), still makes me think its a bit overrated. But its still the best Star Wars movie.
reviews.heading: Makes an excellent case for the best sequel of all time

reviews.content: The greatest film in the franchise and solidified Darth Vader as the greatest villain on the silver screen. Everything about this film is perfect (apart from Vader's tiny cute hologram).
reviews.heading: Impressive... most impressive.

reviews.content: This is the best example of how to make a perfect sequel of a movie. A sequel that clearly differentiates itself from the original whilst building on the characters and the story in thrilling and surprising ways without a fault. An iconic masterpiece of pure escapism filled with thrills and fun.
reviews.heading: HOW TO MAKE A PERFECT SEQUEL.

reviews.content: Before the release of Star Wars (1977], in the theaters, it still had to go through the same steps as any other movie. It too was considered a one shot deal, just like any other movie. It too, like every other film, had to pass the big test at the box office first, before anything else could happen. As everyone knows, this George Lucas directed film, was a huge box office smash, becoming the highest grossing movie of all time. It still held the record in 1980, thus giving the green-light for Lucas to develop a trilogy of films. What makes Empire Strikes Back (1980), so good, is the fact that, the film is one of those bridge-films. It bridges the gap from the first film to the third film. Some number two films in a trilogy, are susceptible to taxing pacing, caused by the need to be a set-up for the big finale in the third film. If done correctly, the film can be a successful bridge-film, while still completing its goal of being an exciting entry in the trilogy. This film accomplishes the goal of being an exciting adventure, full of maturing characters and it comes with a more darker side to it. It also successfully bridges the gap to the third film, Return of the Jedi (1983). It creates major implications for the main cast of characters. It is a cliff-hanger of a story.George Lucas stepped aside as the director for this film, for director Irvin Kershner. Kershner creates a slick, exciting, action-packed adventure, full of dazzle, flare and artistry. It has one of the most incredible soundtracks ever, thanks to legendary composer John Williams. It is pure pleasure watching this film. It is the stuff of legends now. It is still hailed as being the best Star Wars movie ever. The film starts with the main cast together, but splits them up into two stories, that carries the film to the end, eventually bringing them together again, but with a price. The first sub-plot involves Luke (Mark Hamill), meeting the Muppet-like, Jedi master, Yoda (Frank Oz), who begins training Luke to be a Jedi. The other sub-plot involves Han Solo (Harrison Ford), Princess Leia (Carrie Fisher), Chewbacca (Peter Mayhew) and C-3PO (Anthony Daniels), being chased by Darth Vader (Peter Mayhew/James Earl Jones) and enlisting the aid of Lando Calrissian (Billy Dee Williams), the leader of Cloud City. The stage is set for one of the biggest cliff-hangers in film history.9.3 (A Mygrade) = 9 IMDB.
reviews.heading: This film was released wide in the USA on June 20th, 1980

reviews.heading: Perfect

reviews.content: It's really sad to see what star wars has become these days..unoriginal, uninspiring, lacking passion..I can go on and on and on but I just don't have the stomach for it anymore..but this movie right here, star wars empire strikes back, is just so masterfully inspiring and masterfully done. The fact that George Lucas did this movie on his own with his own money should tell you everything you need to know about how amazingly tenacious he is, not only that, he brought the characters to life..making them memorable, believable and most importantly relatable. Yes it's an old movie, yes it feels out dated...but trust me, if you look really past that and focus on its level of storytelling and the amazing writing of the story, you will understand why this movie has a rating of 8.7...most movies today and even in the last decade haven't even gotten close to that. Give it a shot...you won't be disappointed.
reviews.heading: Definitely one of the greatest movies of all time

reviews.content: The Empire Strikes Back brings the viewer further into the galaxy of Star Wars. Following the events of Episode IV: A New Hope, this darker chapter brings newer characters and adventures to the table. We learn more about who we have already come to love in the previous installment and we are able to enjoy a much more well-rounded and fleshed out idea of what Lucas' galaxy far far away should look and feel like. Harrison Ford's portrayal of Han Solo steals the show alongside his companion Chewbacca, played by the late Peter Mayhew. Mark Hamill really ups his game with Luke, making him into a less adolescent and sheltered farm kid, he's learning more about his past and the life he never knew. Carrie Fisher as Leia Organa is the perfect mixture of sass and whit as she shows us that not all space royalty is uppity and useless. Billy Dee Williams knocks it out of the park with his performance as the suave and charismatic Lando Calrissian. With the success of A New Hope, this movie boasts and impressive budget increase. This is shown in the care and detail taken into consideration when seeing all of the creatures and vehicles shown throughout the film. Simply put, this movie CARES. The people involved put forth their best work to bring what the world needed in a constant rotation of mundane and bad sci-fi action flicks coming out around the same time. The Empire Strikes Back is a perfect Star Wars movie in an otherwise very flawed saga. I recommend it for anyone that wants to go on a wild and fun ride through the stars!
reviews.heading: Perfect Star Wars Film in an Imperfect Saga

I found it a bit ridiculous how Ben was speaking to Luke even though he is dead, and he tells him to go to Yoda who I thought was a bit weird and I didn't like him. Around halfway into the movie I wanted it to end because I was just waiting for the story to get better, but it didn't.

reviews.heading: Imaginative and emotional

reviews.content:
Review:
This is basically the fun of the first Star Wars, but faster, more intense pacing, a deeper story line, Mature characters. And of course THE PLOT TWIST TO END ALL PLOT TWISTS....Takeaways:
-The first Star Wars, A New Hope was great. It was a cultural experience for the Movie world. So how would they top the first one? You keep the fun and increase it. Make it non stop. And you also include a deeper story, throw in more maturity, and you make it unpredictable. George Lucas apparently knew all this and he brought this in his sequel, even though he wasn't the director this time around (Irvin Kirshner directed The Empire Strikes Back)-The Epic Battle of Hoth is great and you are seeing most of the snowspeeder action through luke's point of view. You are with him in the Snowsppeder Cockpit.Luke has great development as he goes from curious farmboy to brave but impatient fighter.-YODA!!!!Yoda is similar to an old prophet Sage, a Buddhist monk, wizard, and zen master.Yoda is living true proof that "Size Matters Not"He even teaches this and more things to the impatient student Luke.Luke:"I don't believe it"
Yoda: "That is Why you fail"-Imagine if Han Actually Died when he was being frozen in carbonite. Something of Course That Harrison Ford had lobbied for...-I Gotta HAND it to you Luke, you did well, but don't know how to win a lightsaber duel yet.This Cliffhanger was well done. I am more critical towards current cliffhangers in movies because they copy it off of Star Wars without thinking it through, and they come across as unnerving and horrible. The Empire Strikes back did it very well though, and it is the Best Cliffhanger ending to exist!Vader: "I AM YOUR FATHER."
Luke: THATS IMPOSSIBLLLLEE NOOOOOOO
LUKE CRIES AND FALLS TO HIS DEATH
lol JK.
reviews.heading: The Brilliant and Shocking Second Star Wars

reviews.content: Take a journey to stars with your favourite characters with the best film in whole Star Wars saga. Saga creator George Lucas with him unforgettable plot created not only well-reviewed, but one of the best reviewed film, which no wonder takes the 15th place in IMDb's top. And almosr all of Star Wars' fans name this film best in trilogy.The film concerns the continuing struggles of the Rebel Alliance against the Galactic Empire. During the film, Han Solo, Chewbacca, and Princess Leia Organa are being pursued across space by Darth Vader and his elite forces.In film all is gripping. A unpredictable plot has a lot of twists and turns. What is the phrase worth: "I am your father". It found beginning in 1977 years and it's most popular saga in the world after Marvel and it's the best folm of saga, that says it all.
reviews.heading: Best film in Star Wars saga. (For Aydar Gumarovich XD)

reviews.content: SCORE: 10/10Iconic. That is the first word that comes to mind when I think of this movie. It was flawless. This film has so many amazing moments and arguably one of the most famous scenes of all time.Again, there has to be an understanding of how ahead of it's time this movie was. The scenes on Hoth were some of the most beautifully done scenes in the entire franchise, especially given the time period and technology available at the time. Cracked out Yoda has got to be Top 3 characters in Star Wars and I love how this movie emphasized the similarities between Luke and Anakin. At their core, both Luke and Anakin want to help their friends and both were willing to go against what Obi-Wan told them to achieve what they wanted. And, funny enough, they both end up in a similar situation with their hands cut off.I have the Luke v Vader battle at number 2, but an argument can be made it is the best ahead of the Anakin/Obi-Wan battle on Mustafar. That battle in this movie was so visually pleasing and was the climax of what had been building up in the previous 4 films. And of course, one of the most iconic dialogues of all time occurred when Vader tells says to Luke "I am your Father", which I can imagine was way more impactful at the time of release considering the prequels weren't made.This movie was also packed with many other amazing moments, including the dynamic between Han and Lando and the carbon-freezing of Han. To go along with the theme of being iconic, Han and Leia's moment they shared together when she tells him she loves him and he goes "I know" is the most Han thing ever. This was top tier Star Wars.
reviews.heading: ICONIC

reviews.content: It's a good movie.. I can see that, I'm just starting to think star wars isn't really my thing, I'm not really interested in the characters. I'm sure for the 70s/80s it was pretty revolutionary but now I'm not so sure, I think nostalgia very much clouds the reviews of the first trilogy. However I'm still gonna continue the series and finish all the movies.
reviews.heading: The Empire Strikes Back

reviews.content: After the Empire takes control of the rebel base on Hoth, our core group is divided. Luke Skywalker sets off to continue his Jedi training, while Han, Leia, Chewbacca, and C-3PO are running from the Empire.This is in my opinion the best Star Wars film ever, and one of the best films ever. They take what I consider to be a 10/10 movie in "A New Hope" and take it a step further with great character development, intense action, and improved visuals.First and Foremost across the board great acting. Everyone is on top of their game and gives their best possible performance.We get to see Luke begin his training with Yoda. Yoda is easily one of my favourite Star Wars characters and I love every scene he is in. When Luke finds out that Han and Leia are in trouble he makes the hard decision to save them and face Vader without having finished his training. This of course leads to the iconic reveal that Darth Vader is Luke's father. That moment is one of the greatest moments in cinematic history, everyone watching Star Wars for the first time is surprised by that reveal.Han, Leia, Chewbacca and C-3PO provide us with some sweet action sequences when they are being chased by the empire. They also lead us to the introduction of Lando Calrissian, who is an old friend of Hans.The score by John Williams is just as iconic as before and the new and improved visuals make for an even more immersive experience.This is one of the greatest movies ever made and the fact that they were able to take what was already a phenomenal film and make it better is insanely impressive.10/10.
reviews.heading: Empire Strikes Back Review

reviews.content: "Star Wars- episode V: The Empire strikes back" is directed by "Irvin Kershner.It stars Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher, David Prowse, Billy Dee Williams and Anthony Daniels.After the destruction of the Death Star, the empire has chased the rebellion into hiding. With the rebellion now hiding on the snow planet of "Hoth", "Luke Skywalker" travels to "Dagobah to find Jedi master "Yoda" so he can be trained in the ways of the Jedi.This is and most likely will always be my favourite "Star wars" film. The film is near enough flawless.The positivesThis film is sort of historical mostly because it has one of the greatest twists in cinematic history and has an ending which no one saw coming. The film isn't about the rebels getting another win over the empire, it's about the heroes struggling and managing to survive in the end. It's an emotional ending that is really satisfying and gets you excited for the finale. The twist is something I won't spoil but I'll always remember the first time I saw this film and just being shocked to the core with what was said. The lightsaber fight is the heat of the entire Star Wars saga. It holds plenty of emotion and it's not a fight where "Vader" and "Luke" try to kill each-other. "Vader" is toying with "Luke" to show him the power of the dark side. To try and show how powerful he can become. The characters are well written. Mostly with "Luke". He fails so much in the film. He gives up sometimes but he always tries again later. He has no fear too. He does not hesitate to face "Vader" when he has a vision. His arc also teaches us to be patient. We can't rush into things all the time no matter how much we want to do the thing we're trying to do. His teachings with "Yoda" also teach the audience in some ways. Lessons of patience and not letting your emotions get the better of you are told brilliantly. The acting is great too. Everyone does a better job in this film. The romance that develops between "Han" and "Leia" is charming. It's not awkward, the dialogue is great and the chemistry between the actors is great. The special effects look better than the first film. Thankfully "George" knew this was a great film that didn't need changing much. So we still see a lot of the original effects. Finally, the film is also incredibly funny. So many of the jokes and funny lines are placed perfectly. They don't interfere with the emotional moments and they bring some light hearted moments to an all round sad film.The negativesThe only slight negative I have is that the film isn't laced amazingly. It feels slightly longer than it's runtime. But it's only a small negative that doesn't affect the rating.Conclusion"The Empire strikes back" is near enough a perfect movie. The plot, the twist, action, well written characters, special effects, romance, comedy and themes are all perfect. Apart from the pacing, the film is flawless.I'm going to give "Star wars- episode V: The Empire strikes back" a:10/10.
reviews.heading: A rare perfect sequel.

reviews.content: Well from the 1977 one, which ofcourse I loved a lot and was trying to convince myself it to be a grownups' movie. But with this one, that came crashing down. It is a kids' movie. But that doesn't matter. I still like that. May be being a kid aswell sometimes is good. I wonder about the chidhood of those baby boomers. It must have been terrific. Nowadays kids' movies are nowhere close to this one. And if it is liked by kids and adults alike, then it is one serious contender.They could have been more serious about those light saber duel. Could have been made more realistic, after all that's the signature weapon of the whole franchise. Same goes for Yoda as well.Apart from that everything was amazing. Be it story line, acting and sets.A must watch for kids, adults and old alike.

reviews.content: Everything that could be said about this movie has already been said.My opinion, however, differs from the consensus: first, I think Obi Wan's original story was far more interesting than "the twist that changed cinema". And by Return of the Jedi, having everyone be related felt a little ridiculous (although it was likely done so the audience wouldn't feel bad for Luke).I don't feel TESB upped the stakes; on a personal level, sure. But the climax of A New Hope was concerned with saving entire planets from destruction.The pacing has been amped, and there are showings that Mr. Kasdan was writing with the knowledge that Star Wars was popular and needed to deliver, which it did.84.77/100.
reviews.heading: Do... or do not. There is no try.

reviews.content: My preference goes Return of the Jedi, A new Hope, then this one. I found the characters had better chemistry and the dialogue seemed more natural in the films of 77,83. This one I know the director was attempting to humanize the characters but thought the dialogue was forced and it lacked chemistry.
reviews.heading: Not as good

reviews.content: I am a major fan of the Star Wars universe. But this film, in my opinion, takes the cake as one of, if not, the best Star Wars film of the franchise, especially of the OG trilogy. I love the conflict with Luke and his destiny, how he is all for training, and completely obedient to his master. But at the same time, he is so willing to leave it to help his friends and the rebellion, despite the words of Master Yoda and Obi-Wan. It almost seems like he will abandon it for them, which both shows his loyalty and stubborness. And this episode, even without an 'actual ending', begins to foreshadow Luke's battle with himself and the dark side for the next episode. All-in-all, the amazing story combined with the great visuals for its time is a very good film, and remains my favorite.
reviews.heading: One of, if not, the best film of the franchise

reviews.heading: THE BEST SEQUEL EVER

reviews.content: This film is as Star Wars as Star Wars gets in that it is one of if not the best story told in the franchise. Empire Strikes Back takes everything that was good about A New Hope and just completely expands upon it. It is arguably the greatest sequel in cinematic history.Each character is given more emotional depth including Luke, Leia, Han, and even Vader this time. A New Hope is a fun movie, this movie feels more like an emotional experience in comparison. This is the first film in which the Imperial March, one of the best songs created for a movie ever is heard. Also, this movie contains probably the most shocking reveal in all of cinematic history.The sets are more grand, the effects are more spectacular, and the music is absolutely some of the best in all of Star Wars. The film sets genuinely feel completely real. From Hoth to Dagobah to Bespin the locations in this film are so incredibly detailed and well made. Dagobah especially feels like a completely different planet. None of the sets even feel like sets. They feel like real places. Also the special effects are marvelous especially for its time. The asteroid belt scene in particular is not only breathtaking to see but the music mixed in as well makes it so much fun to watch.Which brings me to the action. Much more fun and much more grand in comparison to A New Hope. The opening Hoth battle is such a great scene not only because of the special effects and the captivating action but also because of the stakes. The fact that we are following all the characters and they are all doing something makes it feel like they are actually in trouble and it makes for an engrossing scene. The fight with Luke and Vader is also a great action scene. The scene where Luke is looking for his friends and runs into Vader. The lack of music, the choreography, and all the colors work together to tell the story. One of the best set ups to a fight, like ever. The fight itself is very emotional for both characters which leads up to the big reveal at the end. Luke willingly chose death over joining Vader. It's a cliffhanger, literally.I feel like the Yoda stuff is shorter than it should be. Don't get me wrong I think the training scenes with Yoda on Dagobah are great. But, it feels too short and almost underwhelming. It starts off very funny when we meet Yoda, I love that scene after Luke crashes. I also think the dialogue between Yoda and Luke as well as Yoda and Ben is really well written. Yoda feels like a goofball at first, but quickly begins to come out as a genuine and wise character. All of those scenes are extremely quotable as well like Yoda says some really smart things. In the end it feels like Lukes training is extremely rushed and I understand it's because he chose to leave, but still I would have liked to see more. That doesn't mean I don't appreciate the scenes we did get. The tie fighter scene is awesome and I think about Yoda's quotes to Luke on a daily basis.Overall, The Empire Strikes Back is honestly a masterpiece of cinema. It is one of the best movies ever made without a doubt. The characters all have so much more depth to them. It completely steps it up in comparison to A New Hope. In terms of the character development, special effects, script, and execution. There is never a dull moment, and it is filled with iconic moments. The whole third act is so emotionally powerful. The scene where they lose Han, and then the Vader and Luke scene afterwards. Such well shot, emotional and beautifully filmed scenes. It ends with one of the best cliffhangers ever. Everyone is on a low note, and no one knows what's gonna happen next. The Empire Strikes Back is nothing shy of a masterpiece. *chefs kiss*I like New Hope better because it's much more simple and fun. Revenge of the Sith is my favorite, easily.
reviews.heading: Easily One of the Best Films Ever Made

reviews.content: The Empire Strikes Back (1980) is a movie in my DVD collection that I recently watched again on Disney+. The storyline picks up where Star Wars left off with the rebellion building their army and the evil Empire rebounding from losing the Death Star. Luke will try to master the powers of the force by searching for a new Jedi to train him; meanwhile, as he digs into his past he discovers more about how he became a Jedi to begin with.This movie is directed by Irvin Kershner (Robocop 2) and stars Mark Hamill (Sushi Girl), Harrison Ford (Clear and Present Danger), Carrie Fisher (Sorority Row), Billy Dee Williams (Nighthawks) and James Earl Jones (Coming to America).The Empire Strikes Back was always one of my favorites in the original trilogy. The opening yeti scene was fantastic and a great way tp start the film. The Princess and Hans scenes were hilarious and the banter makes you laugh no matter how many times you've seen it. Yoda is a legendary character introduced in this film and the Hans stasis scene is always sad. The final Luke vs Vader scene is also legendary and fun to watch unfold.Overall this is among the all time great science fiction movies that is an absolute must see. This is an easy 10/10.
reviews.heading: This is among the all time great science fiction movies that is an absolute must see

reviews.content: This movie is the perfect example, on how to do a sequel right. This is easily the best Star Wars movie ever made. The action is much better and advanced, than in the pervious one. The villains are both amazing. Darth Vader established himself, as one of the most iconic villains of all time in this movie. The emotion is well implemented and it fits very nicely with the story. Lando Calrissian was a very neat addition to the group, which I very much enjoyed. Yoda was amazing in this movie as well. There is basically nothing to complain about. This is another one of the perfect movies.

reviews.heading: The Best From Trilogie

reviews.content: Every time I revisit the good old first trilogy I wonder: did Georg Lucas spend all this creativity on the first three movies or did he have some ghost writer or maybe he got the story dictated by a supernatural being? Without any doubt, those three first movies of the ST franchise are still and maybe for all eternity gems and milestones to the sci-fi genre, but almost everything else that was produced and published after Return of the Jedi is in comparison bad, really bad, with a very few exceptions (Rogue One was good). But maybe the saying even a blind hen sometimes finds a grain of corn just fits too well to Mr. Lucas. Anyway, he gave us these three epic movies, and for these treasures I am grateful in all eternity, and the rest I can just ignore. Amen.
reviews.heading: Maybe the Best of Them All

reviews.content: Beautiful Movie. Absolutely perfect, great story telling, good camara work, nice acting. Star Wars is such a big part of my childhood and this lovie is a big reason why. It makes me remember what good days I had with my friends and why i fell in love with art and movies.
reviews.heading: Star Wars V

reviews.content: Luke Skywalker is not a virtuoso. He misses the charisma. Despite everything, the boy shows great potential. It's undeniable. A potential large enough for the Emperor himself to worry about it. This rough diamond Luke nevertheless needs to be worked on otherwise it may end up in the wrong hands. And because without technology, power is nothing. The twink needs to break his teeth. That's why Obi-Wan Kenobi sends him to Yoda. In contact with Yoda, this young Cub will learn everything. Starting with unlearning. The old Master will teach him the basics. To progress, Luke must get rid of all his certainties that prevent us from seeing clearly. It becomes a blank page. Yoda is not trying to format it, at least not officially. Rather, it seeks to empty the mind of all the parasitic caches that consumer society imposes on us. Draw a line on all these urban legends. Yoda turns out to be a better coach than a psychiatrist. Rather than worrying about why, he is more interested in how because it is hyper-pragmatic. His method works because when Luke faces his father, he is able to resist his enticing promises of power.

So I am probably going against most Star Wars fans who rate this as the best in the saga but for me it's a great movie but not the best. I can't really put my finger on why. I found the whole trip to see Yoda a bit boring and it went on for too long. Hoth was great but did not see why we had to spend first ten mins watching Luke get captured by the yeti type monster. The chase in the asteroid field was all a bit yawn. That being said there were some fantastic highlights such as Hoth battle, Cloud City stuff and of course the Vader/Luke father bit. I just found it all a bit trying to be edgy in places. Great movie but not the best in the saga for me.
reviews.heading: Great movie but not the best in the saga

reviews.content: Yoda once said "Do or do not. There is not try." Well, I DO love this movie! The lighting, the costume, the sound effects! Pretty much EVERYTHING is improved upon! And it all leads up to one of the best plot twists in movie history ever!

reviews.content: I am a stubborn person and I do not understand the first time. Trying to comprehend the popularity of Star Wars, I sat down to the second part, which is actually episode five. reviews.heading: I'm your father

reviews.content: Star Wars, having barely entered the world's screens, became a classic of cinema. The history of the confrontation between the Alliance and the Galactic Empire has captured the imagination of millions of people. The audience simply demanded that the creators continue.George Lucas, the creator of the saga, after a triumphant 4 episodes, gave way to the director's chair to Irvin Kershner, his teacher. Lucas himself, after moral and physical exhaustion associated with the filming of the last film, limited himself to the role of screenwriter and producer.The continuation of the story came out more juicy and darker than the original picture. We were shown new planets - Hoth, Dagobach, Bespin. Introduced new interesting characters - Yoda, Lando Calrissian, Boba Fett and Emperor Palpatine. The characters have become more voluminous. The entire galaxy has become more interesting and immense. Also in episode 5, the legendary melody of John Williams, the March of the Empire, was played for the first time.It is in episode 5 that we are fully revealed the concept of the Great Power and its Light and Dark sides, which will be the subject of discussion among fans and teachers for a long time to come.The movie is fast paced and I never looked at my watch while watching. Of course, there is more darkness in the film and a certain sense of hopelessness in front of the huge power of the Empire, but even with all this, episode 5 still leads us to the light! There is always a chance to win. Just don't give up!10 of 10.
reviews.heading: Shadows of the Empire

reviews.content: Star Wars. A classic, the same space opera that you always want to watch.This film always gives me a very strong feeling of nostalgia, lightsabers, stormtroopers, all this is a wonderfully written lore, well, the most cherished *Spoiler* "Luke, I'm your father."Mr. Lucas, thank you for this.The picture is still beautiful, the effects too, and it's not even in the blue-ray version.Harrison Ford, this man is always in my heart.I'think it's best episode on Star Wars.(Somebody donate me lightsaber please.)

I consider this episode of the Star Wars Saga as his Magnum Opus, for excellence is found throughout the film.

reviews.heading: game

reviews.content: The Empire Strikes Back is the last Star Wars property ever made that I genuinely love. It marked an early peak for the franchise and unfortunately it all went down hill from here (with some minor spikes later on).I genuinely have difficulty finding things wrong with this film, even in the special edition versions. The pacing is slower, yet more methodical and introspective. The character work is more well done, and the acting has gone up a couple notches.This is also the film that made Darth Vader iconic. Though Star Wars was his first appearance, he had much more screen time here and was much more of a threat. Of course there is the infamous "No, I am your father" twist that changed our perspective of the events of both this film and the previous one.There was a genuine effort to continue and expand the story and setting of this universe. This movie is not interested with fan-pandering and retreading the same water, but breaking new ground and the result is a different, but superior sequel.The Empire Strikes Back is a darker and more mature film than its predecessor. There is less hopeful triumph and more loss and consequences. There is less black and white and much more grey. It continued the simple plot of the original, but made it just a bit more complicated and a lot more interesting.The best part of Star Wars was its structure and pacing, whereas Empire's greatest strength is its character work and themes.I should also mention that this was the film that introduced Yoda and further explained what the Force really is. That vague, poetic description that he gave was all we really needed. It was a plot device that enriched the mythos of the franchise.Luke, the main character was good in the original, but like most aspects of this film, he is expanded upon and improved as a result. His struggle is with his own impulsiveness and over reliance on strength and power, which is what he needs to work on if he is to become a true Jedi. He deliberately goes against the wishes of his master to save his friends, but fails and loses a hand as a result. He learns the truth that neither Obi-Wan, nor Yoda ever told him, which gives their actions and words (or the lack thereof) a different meaning in this context.The Jedi masters are not without their flaws after all.The Empire Strikes Back is a movie about facing the consequences for your actions, whether they be good or evil. It is realistic and grounded in that sense. It presents the audience with a story about struggle and failure and is not afraid to shy away from the more difficult aspects of life personified in this filmIf I said much more about Empire, I would consider it an essay so I should wrap up. As a whole, this movie is incredible and thought provoking. There is not a single bad or tedious moment in this movie and hits all the right beats. The only problem with this film is that it ends and the franchise never reaches these heights again. Not even close.I give The Empire Strikes Back a 10/10 with the title of "Outstanding!"
reviews.heading: The Early Peak of the Star Wars Franchise

reviews.content: This is a Hollywood masterclass on how to make a good sequel. 'A New Hope' was a fantastic movie, and 'The Empire Strikes Back' improved on it greatly. Awesome story-telling, great action, the movie is just wonderful. Go watch it. 10/10.

The music that comes out every time Darth Vader appears is truly heartbreaking.Everyone will admit it's the best of Star Wars movie. I loved it.
reviews.heading: The Empire Strikes Back..

reviews.content:
So my next step in watching Star Wars films is the 2nd film released The Empire Strikes Back and I'm going to spoil the review for anybody watching this is my favourite film I have ever seen so expect me to be very positive about this film. The premise of the film sees Luke Skywalker travel to the planet Dagobah and learn from a Jedi Master in order to improve his skills, while Leia, Han, Chewbacca & C-3PO are on the run from The Empire with Darth Vader in charge of everything.Main Character
There is sometimes some criticism of Mark Hamill's performance in the first two Star Wars films because he does complain and wine quite a bit. However, I think this helps make this character feel interesting to me, the other two jedi's we meet in the first two films in Obi-Wan & Yoda are very wise and all knowing so easy to respect but hard to relate to. Luke is us the audience, we don't understand the teachings of the Jedi and we get frustrated easily, Luke makes mistakes as a character which makes him easier to root for as he feels very human compared to these other characters who feel like gods. This film does a great job in making Luke flawed but also making us care about him and want to see him succeed in his mission despite these flaws.Supporting Characters
As mentioned in my previous review Harrison Ford as Han Solo & Carrie Fish as Leia are brilliant supporting characters and they are great in this film together. They have so much charisma and there chemistry together is off the charts (probably due to real life chemistry), they have some of the most iconic scenes in film history together in this film and there romance really evolves in the film and feels very natural and appropriate for the two characters on screen. Now onto possibly the star of the show the character of Darth Vader, in A New Hope we are given a brief introduction to Vader but in this film he is centre stage and he is the embodiment of pure evil in this film. He is menacing and you are scared of his power as we aren't really shown that in the previous film, he is very commanding and you learn more about his character that makes him even more interesting then he was in the previous film. Frank Oz voices Yoda in the film and he was a great addition to the film, you can really see how wise Yoda is as a character and I really liked his dynamic with Luke in the film as you see two people pretty much at different points of life and how they treat things which leads to them clashing. Billy Dee Williams plays Lando Carrissian, a smuggler that are heroes meet and he also has loads of charisma and charm to him even though you can tell he maybe isn't as honest as he lets on and like Han from the previosu film he has his own motivations to help the team.Story
This film takes risks with its story by splitting the characters up into two different storylines but it really pays off. You have the slower but really interesting personal story with Luke & Yoda and you have the faster more exciting romantic story involving Han & Leia. They both mesh incredibly well and they both give an audience member different things to enjoy and it allows the pacing to feel perfect and well done. Obviously this film has some twists in it that are very well known but I wn't mention them specifically in case there is somebody who doesn't know about it, but it is all handled perfectly and really adds drama to this film but also the future films aswell that was pretty revolutionary at the time and even holds up now even though I know the twists.Script
The script for this film is so well written, the dialogue makes the characters feel so real and the drama is amped up in this one to truly make you care about the characters and the plight that they are in. The humour is good too especially with Han & Leia as it fits there characters perfectly and feels right for them and their romance. Also the twists are perfectly handled and written brilliantly to allow you to really sink them in and understand them.Style
This film's style is darker then A New Hope but it feels right as the heroes are plunged into a darker story and as the title of the film suggests the villains are all over them from very early on. In terms of action scenes The Battle of Hoth at the beginning of the film is one of my favourite battles not just in Star Wars history but in film history. Also the lightsaber battle between Vader & Luke is faster and just as personal as the one between Vader & Obi-Wan making it more exciting and a much better watch. Also John Williams score is even better in this film and really adds to the suspense and the darker story that is being told. I should also mention that I watched the newer Blu Ray version but unlike A New Hope the changes are very small and I actually thought they were fine and didn't change the film one bit.Overall
Overall, I literally struggle to find any faults with this movie. It is the perfect middle part of a trilogy and should be watched as that so watch A New Hope, Empire Strikes Back & Return Of The Jedi in a short time frame to truly appreciate the development of the characters and the story. With this being my favourite film of all time I heavily recommend this film and the other two films in the trilogy.Rating - 10/10.
reviews.heading: My Favourite Film Ever

reviews.content: I love this movie so incredibly much it's so nostalgic for me watching it as a kid but even excluding that this movie is an apsalute gem giving us tonnes of memorable characters and lines that have been so iconic. The movie is iconic with sets and props that have inspired to many other science fiction movies and movies in general for years to come.
reviews.heading: "impressive, most impressive"

reviews.content: Whenever I call a movie a perfect sequel, I usually say it's also an imperfect movie, the empire strikes back would be one of the first examples I would give out, I do think that it kind of has a slow start and some of the C-3PO stuff is unnecessary. But that doesn't bring down the fact that it's one of the best sequels of all time and of my personal favorite star wars movies, everything that happens after this revolves around the twist in this movie, and then they made the prequels and revenge of the sith explains everything, I prefer the empire strikes back over revenge of the sith as a sequel, but as a movie, I prefer revenge of the sith, this movie also has a lot heart and stakes. So it's not perfect but it's still great.
reviews.heading: Star wars originals #2: the empire strikes back

reviews.content: I can't review "Empire" man! What am I supposed to say? "it's good, yeah". It's one of the founding films that makes up my cultural mentality. I've been watching it for most of the 40 years that I've been alive. Anyway... let's put something down.The destruction of the Death Star did not signal the end of the war against the Empire. From an Ice Station on the planet Hoth, the rebel command structure is operating, but the Empires probe droids have found them, and an attack is imminent. Han Solo (Harrison Ford) delays again paying off his debt to Jabba The Hutt to remain part of the struggle but his escape from Hoth does not go well, and leads to a fateful meeting on Bespin. Luke (Mark Hamill) is told to visit the Dagobah system, to find a reclusive Jedi Master for further training.It's the dark cool one, isn't it. That's why we like "Empire". There's no happy ending, things are much worse at the end that they are at the beginning, but they knew the third one was coming to put it right. I can't imagine what it was like to hear the twist for the first time. It's now, of course, one of the most quoted (misquoted) lines in the history of cinema and an Iconic moment, but then it must have been quite the stunning moment.The visual effects are still pretty solid. I suspect I was watching another version of it that Lucas tinkered with in '97 and maybe even again after. I wish Disney Plus had the option for you to choose which version of the film you wanted to watch, but that's not the case yet.I'm going to stop writing, as I doubt most people will read this, let alone decide whether or not to watch "Empire" based on it but, on the off chance you're still here, it's good yeah!
reviews.heading: Hoth and bothered.

reviews.content: This is the pinnacle of all Star Wars. The only SW film which is truly great, at least in my opinion. Let's first talk about the story. Certainly the film started off on a wrong foot as it was very much 'A New Hope' once again, but then it pretty quickly changed tone and went into a completely different territory.It became much more mature, sophisticated and infinitely more involving in its second and third act. It also became a much better crafted, much more engaging adventure with some incredible high-spirited sequences such as the asteroid chase scene which is the finest action scene here. Lando is solid but not too memorable and Boba Fett is entirely forgettable and overrated, but the part with Han and Leia is still excellent and very well done.But of course the highlight is Luke's storyline. It is the greatest Jedi storyline so far and the one which is emotional and also stupendously well told with great dialogue. I loved that swamp planet and it was a perfect location for Luke's training. And of course the fight with Vader is unforgettable, the twist remains great to this day and the ending is an excellent tease for the sequel. The film is very much a second, middle chapter and although some may have a problem with it, I really liked that it did not have a proper beginning and ending. It truly is the ultimate middle chapter in a trilogy.
reviews.heading: This is the pinnacle of all Star Wars.

reviews.content: Luke Skywalker goes from naive country boy to that over in a soldier and that he is maturing and growing very much big.As sexual tension in the air there for Leia with her feistiness and Han Solo with his tough talking no nonsense treasure hunter.In order to buy Han and Leia time to escape. Luke goes to find Jedi master Yoda to train in order to defeat Darth Vader who hides a secret of his own.But in doing so that it may mean sacrifices there.Billy Dee Williams who should had been a bigger star as he is Lando Calrissian a breakout character like Han.Darth and Luke lightsaber duel is something else and brings a lot of angst and tension there.
reviews.heading: Huge Character Development

reviews.content: The gold standard of Star Wars films, Empire outdoes ANH on every level with a deeper look at the characters, superior acting, special effects and story. The only film in the franchise without a giant finale, Empire transcended blockbuster movie making with Irvin Kerschner showing George how these movies should be done. The Michael Jordan of Star Wars. 10/10.

reviews.heading: Best star wars movie ever!!

reviews.content: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back is truly masterful. The acting is convincing, highlighting the intelligent emotional depth and well developed character arcs present throughout the film. Interesting new characters build the intrigue of the feature, too. From beginning to end, the storyline is thrilling, with intense battle scenes full of great visuals and sound. There are few plot holes, the writers impressively delivering a largely seamless, constantly moving story that still has time for pause. Various comedic moments cleverly contrast, and in turn compliment the more serious undertones present. Dialogue throughout proves especially meaningful, delivering many iconic lines. The concluding sequences were highly satisfactory, as well. Overall, this feature is a wonderful addition to the franchise's lore and cinema itself.
reviews.heading: An amazing sequel

reviews.content: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back. Go to the dark side of the force. Great sequel to the Space Saga. Yes, the sequel looks darker than the first film, but that doesn't make it worse. New heroes and new villains, all accompanied by great music.
reviews.heading: Go to the dark side of the force.

reviews.content: Most Sequels are garbage but empire strikes back introduces and archives so much and it will always be considered it a game changer no wonder its an iconic peace of film.
reviews.heading: Empire Strikes Back

reviews.content: The momentum throughout the largely-adored Star Wars instalment isn't exactly energetic enough to win against A New Hope. So overall, it's a very well-constructed sequel that continues with the epic sci-fi action, but is mainly disappointing.The new director, Irvin Kershner, definitely builds onto George Lucas's original and clever direction. The force, the explosive effects, the appealing battles and the cool robots are all brought back, except they're not as fascinating this time... The real flaw is the exceedingly unhurried pace, and it manages to coat all the creativity.Although The Empire Strikes Back leaves off with a reasonably satisfying touch, it fails to leave you excited for the next movie. It's a likeable flick worth experiencing in the cinema, but it's adored a little too highly. But still, there's absolutely no doubt that the big fans of the series will love it.If you liked this review, check out the full review and other reviews at aussieboyreviews.
reviews.heading: Good Story, Great Action... Unfortunate Pace...

reviews.content: Empire strikes back is amazing with great characters,an amazing plot twist,and a film that serves as a good middle chapter to the original trilogy. And by the way what character does big bank hank compare himself to?
reviews.heading: The best Star Wars movie there is

reviews.content: Takes the first Star Wars and improves literally everything- many of the shortcomings of that first film are either outright fixed or at least made less noticeable.Special effects are significantly improved (less CGI additions in the bluray version, too. And if they are there, they're generally less noticeable)Bigger and more ambitious action scenesPacing is just flawlessDialogue is sharper; the banter between characters is much betterIt's better shot from a visual standpoint, too. The first Star Wars had plenty of iconic images for sure, but this one just feels more cinematic, with better camerawork, lighting, and use of colour.The new locations are also great.Uses a satisfying three-act structure that still somehow feels exciting and unpredictable (if you've not seen it before, of course)Characters are fantastic, as are the new additions to the cast (Yoda's scenes are gold- every single second of them)Empire is more menacing, and the heroes are in near constant peril. Death Vader being properly unchained from Tarkin made him the iconic villain he's known as today.That twist is so well known by this point, but if you try to imagine being in a theatre and hearing that for the first time in 1980, it would have been mind blowingEvery character now openly finds C3PO annoying, so his comic relief goes from laughing "with him" (which scarcely worked in the first film) to more or less laughing "at him," which is way funnier.It's dark by Star Wars standards but it's not depressing. There's plenty of fun and action, and a surprising amount of humour that largely works- it balances the seriousness with the excitement and the humour perfectly.Ending satisfies while also leaving you hungry for the concluding chapter (which had its moments, but seems to get a little worse upon each revisit, while Empire Strikes Back only seems to get better with age).This is absolutely a near masterpiece that's hard to fault to be honest... but you didn't need my ramblings to tell you that.

Is Godfather: Part II a masterpiece and an excellent sequel? Of course! It's a classic! But, hear me out...The Empire Strikes Back isn't just a terrific follow up to Star Wars, it's a terrific film in its own right! For those who loved Star Wars, it's sequel is sure to loved even more! With its darker themes, quicker plot, excellent character development and, not to forget that epic climax...this has to be declared the best sequel ever produced!

my favourite movie of all time.10/10.
reviews.heading: Legendary

reviews.content: Honestly, I just absolutely adore this film, and the further I travel in life, the more that I discover that I'm not the only one. In fact it seems to pretty much be the favourite of all of the Star Wars films, probably because there is so much happening, and also because of the big reveal at the end. In fact, the big reveal was kept so secret that only Mark Hammil, James Earl Jones, and the creators knew about it, which was why it was such a shock.In a way this film pretty much feels like it is the middle part of the trilogy, particularly since the end isn't really all that conclusive. In fact, it sort of feels more like a phyrric victory, though the fact that Han Solo has been captured, the Empire hasn't really suffered a defeat, and that the film closes with Luke and Leah simply standing on the deck looking out at the rebel fleet is a clear indication that there is more to come.Yet, I felt that this was the best ending of any of the Star Wars films, though it is probably the only one that could get away with it. The first one had to have a fairly conclusive ending, namely because there wasn't really much indication that there would be any more after that, and of course Return of the Jedi had to be conclusive because there was no indication that there was going to be any more after that either (the latest trilogy came about after Disney had purchased the franchise).I guess the thing that I loved about the film is that there is so much action, from the battle on the ice planet of Hoth, to the asteroid chase. In fact, the asteroid chase is probably the best of any film that I have ever seen - there isn't many space opera's that I've seen that happen to have a full blown chase through an asteroid belt. Yet there are some nice touches as well, particularly the commander that keels over and dies, and the holographic connection cuts out when his ship is hit by an asteroid. Oh, and the Emperor is also revealed in this film - in fact I'm not entirely sure whether he was even mentioned in the first film, though I probably should have paid a bit more attention when I watched it a couple of weeks previously.Honestly, there is little that I can probably say that hasn't already been said, and since this film seriously has a huge cult following, or at least the series does, then no doubt this is one of the films that pretty much everybody has seen, or at least everybody who has wanted to see this film has basically seen this film. The other interesting thing is that it didn't seem to be as altered as the previous film was, but as I have indicated previously, these films really didn't need to be altered since they were good enough as is.
reviews.heading: The Best of the Franchise

reviews.content: Straight up, this movie is just so enjoyable to watch. I couldn't tell you the amount of quotable moments or movie influence this film has had at the time of its release. The characters, as if they weren't good enough already, are thrown into completely different scenarios to what they were presented with in 'A New Hope', and it's because of that, we as the audience only grow to love them more. Han Solo's character in this film has changed significantly from the last film, and we are now presented with this half rebel, half scoundrel character that is trying to become a better person and leave his life of smuggling behind, only for him to be chased by the galactic empire across the galaxy alongside Leia, Chewbacca and C-3PO. Luke skywalker begins training to become a Jedi, but still has this reckless trait about him that ultimately leads to his defeat in an impulsive and deadly duel against Darth Vader, who reveals to Luke in one of the most memorable parts of the movie that he is Luke's father. Combined with breathtaking special effects and immersive storytelling, this film has risen to become one of the most influential films of all time, inspiring captivating and exciting storytelling and giving birth to the modern cliffhanger ending that many blockbuster films utilise to this very day. It is without any doubt, that Star Wars episode V: The Empire Strikes Back, is an iconic piece of cinema that continues to be treasured and adored by many, and a film many would agree to be one of the greatest of all time.
reviews.heading: One of the most breathtaking and exciting films of all time

reviews.heading: I am your father!

reviews.content: Empire Strikes Back is highly regarded as a masterpiece and one of the best sequels ever made, and it deserves all of the praise it gets. After all this time, it's still one of the best Star Wars movies to date and the best of the original trilogy.The opening Hoth sequence is extremely tense, dramatic, well-paced, and explosive. The cold environment works as a great way to show how much darker and grim this film is going to be. Luke's training with Yoda on Dagobah is awe-inspiring and this subplot has a ton of character development. We learn much more about the force and what it truly means to be a Jedi, Luke's character flaws are explored, and we get more hints and Obi-Wan and Vader's past. The Empire chasing the Millennium Falcon is intense and suspenseful. Darth Vader's fearsome presence and brutal executions give chills. Lando's betrayal and Han being frozen in Carbonite is impactful. Vader and Luke's lightsaber duel is one of the finest, most brutal and nail-biting fights in all of Star Wars, and Vader's reveal that he is Luke's father is powerful. The entire movie is an immensely thrilling and entertaining ride.All of the performances are top notch, and so is the character development and dialogue. We get to see Luke learning how to become a Jedi and a deep exploration of his character flaws, Han and Leia fall in love (while Han continues to be his awesome witty self), Leia opens herself up to relationships, and Vader gets a lot more screentime in this one. We see more of how ruthless, passionate, hateful, terrifying, and selfish he is, all of which make him such a great Sith, but also a small bit of his softer side at the end when he speaks with Luke through the force, foreshadowing his change in Return of the Jedi. We are also introduced to Yoda, who is an inspiring and unique mentor figure, and the puppet used to portray him has aged quite well in it's execution.Speaking of which, like the entire original trilogy, the special effects are stunning and groundbreaking, with lots of astounding practical sets, puppets, animatronics and miniatures and gorgeous green screen and matte shots (though in terms of the latter two, these haven't aged the best, but they were top notch for their time). And finally, John Williams continues to outdo himself with the amazing, exhilarating musical score. This movie introduced the Imperial March, perhaps the best villain theme in cinema history.A definite masterpiece all around.

reviews.heading: How do you follow a classic? By making another classic

reviews.content: Visually, this is easily the best of the original "Star Wars" trilogy. There are reasons for that. For instance, the ridiculous little puppets meant to act as alien creatures. "The Empire Strikes Back" uses them the least. And one of them is so surprisingly good in both how it looks and how the plot handles it this creature with big ears feels real and is a great addition to the big picture. Then there are the special effects and the sets that, obviously, were made in a time when making them was a much harder process than in the twenty-first century, but they look real. All this physical material ages well. Even the "special editions" are not an obstacle.The plot is structured in a different way than the one from three years earlier. It does not have that clear line between the loud and the quiet parts of the story. Different things are not placed far from one another. They are numerous and aren't given as much room to breathe as the last time. The overall tone of the picture is, apparently, the reason for many to regard "Episode V" as the best in the whole franchise. It is dark and bold for a mainstream movie, which isn't something you often find.Still, there are things to criticize, like the battle on the ice planet. Of course, it is beautiful, but the design of the imperial walking machines, as menacing as it may look, makes no sense. They are big, clumsy and slow. Then there is the plot itself. We have this huge imperial fleet of colossal starships with great firepower chasing one little rebel ship because the person in charge of that fleet wants to get their hands on one particular rebel person. Of course, the prior movie is proof enough of how important that one young rebel fighter is, but still, how about the rest of the rebel fleet? The movie has it in the beginning and at the very end. For the most part it is ignored. Of course, one can say that this isn't exactly science fiction, which is correct. But the dark and seemingly serious tone of the picture and some of the stupidity in the plot are not good friends.

reviews.heading: Luke I Am Your Father

reviews.content: Because practically everything has been said about this movie, I am going to make a commentary out of the ordinary, in which I am going to criticize only a very important aspect of its script which I don't like. As every true geek knows, George Lucas liked the book "The Hero with a Thousand Faces" by Joseph Campbell so much that he incorporated many influences from it into the Star Wars script. Campbell studied myths and religions from around the world and he realized that there is a story that is repeated insistently in many cultures because it seems to convey a very important knowledge about the human soul. It is what has been called the "Hero's Journey" or "Monomyth". So Lucas wrote the Star Wars script following the steps of this mythical story.Luke enters the Death Star, just as Theseus entered the labyrinth of the Minotaur (a labyrinth that could well symbolize the intricacies of the human mind). When Luke finally confronts the "dragon" Darth Vader, he discovers that he is his father, and Luke is afraid that Vader's evil could also potentially be inside him. If his father fell into the dark side, perhaps he could do so as well. Thus, for example, Siegfried became cursed after killing the dragon Fafnir, because he kept the ring of power that the beast kept in his cave. The Hero's Journey is, in short, an inner psychological travel to learn more about the good and the bad within a person. The Jedi are so skilled in this self-knowledge and their wisdom about the force is so great that they can have premonitions about the future. That is, because they know themselves very well, they also believe they know what other individuals in the universe are like, so they will be able to predict their future behaviors. The failure that seems to me to have the Monomyth, and thus the Star Wars saga, is that a man, by introspection, can know himself, but not those who are different of him. It is very unlikely that a moral human being can predict the behavior of a psychopath who has no conscience and feels no remorse when he commits perverse acts. On the contrary, this technique can lead him to make fatal mistakes in predicting the future behavior of individuals who are psychopaths. A person capable of empathy will hardly understand the personality of a conscienceless egoist who only seeks his own interest, regardless of the people he has to destroy to achieve it. So the jedi have a more complicated job than they think to know all the sith and predict their selfish and evil future moves. Is Luke as similar to his father as he seems to think? Could he go from being a defender of freedom to becoming an evil galactic dictator? Or is he so different from his father that he would be incapable of join the dark side? Probably only a genetic expert could answer these questions.There is no doubt that we should enjoy the impressive visual spectacle that George Lucas has created with his galactic saga, but I think we should always keep in mind that the Monomyth has a very weak point and is not the answer to all the questions about the human being. Introspection is useful for a person to understand himself, but not to understand those who are different. Believing the opposite, can be a very dangerous thing. So it seems to me that the jedi and George Lucas need to consider that knowing the galaxy and the people who live in it is much more complicated than they assume. Some sith can be far more cold-hearted and villainous than a good jedi can imagine.
reviews.heading: Star Wars, the Monomyth of Joseph Campbell and the psychopaths.

reviews.heading: The perfect movie

reviews.content: Just before the release of Rise of the Skywalker, I had decided to watch every single Star Wars movie so that I could finally understand the memes and also catch up on time. So as I watched The Empire Strikes Back, I was actually really disappointed. Because of how much people speak about it, I was expecting it to be something more than that. But as I grew up, I started appreciating it more and more. Why I hated it earlier and why I like it now, I'll explain it further in the review.Back when I saw this movie for the first time, I was getting more and more surprised at every scene. I had heard about all the characters like Yoda, Darth Vader, Han Solo, Chewbacca, R2D2, C3PO etc, but I didn't know what was their deal. I did know Yoda was a green guy who was very skilled, but I didn't know anything else about him. This is the reason why I liked his introduction so much. The problem was, however, that I already knew he was Yoda. So all that acting, I wasn't going to buy it.Similarly the Darth Vader scene was a huge bummer. The way people used to describe it was as if he removes his mask and says it with an emotional background music. But instead he just simply speaks it out in a claustrophobic environment, with the background music completely quenching the impact. It was in no way as good as everyone described it. I might have liked the scene if I didn't already know about it, which basically shows how this movie suffered from the success it received.The camera quality has also aged very poorly. I don't know why, but somehow I just can't watch old movies. I get bored and start feeling sleepy very quickly. It happened as I watched Episode IV, it happened as I watched Superman and it happened as I watched The Godfather. I actually slept at the part where Luke is training on Yoda's planet. This is the first movie ever that I watched in two different days. Once as I slept and once after I woke up the next day. And somehow it left such an impact that even today I feel sleepy whenever I watch any Star Wars movie.With all the bad things said, now let's move on to why I like this movie now. First of all the whole idea of a space opera is so awesome. I have always been very much into astronomy since I was a kid so an entire movie series made around this is something like a dream for me. I can imagine this could also be true for many kids in the 60's and 70's. The CGI is quite awesome for the time. Like I said about the Darth Vader scene or the Yoda scene, they must have looked so cool when they were seen for the first time. The part where Han is embossed rises too much tension, since he's such a likeable character and now he's at stake. If George Lucas went by his multiple movies idea instead of a franchise then this could have been such an awesome take.I feel really mad at myself that I learnt about all the spoilers from this movie except for Han getting embossed. I wish I could rewatch this after having removed everything I know from my memory. This movie should be re-released in 4K HDR so that I don't fall asleep while watching it again. It is a pinnacle in the Star Wars series and I really hope the franchise can return back to this level.
reviews.heading: I will remove a star each time a toxic fan marks my review unhelpful, and increase one if they mark my review helpful

reviews.content: Another fantastic edition to the Original Trilogy with the most famous sequel perhaps in all of Sci FI Movie history with Luke being revealed that he is in fact Darth Vader's son or Yoda's first ever appearance. Again like with A New Hope, the special effects of Empire Strikes Back and CGI has aged tremendously wellThe story is solid but the summary that IMDB stated for this movie as Darth Vader and Boba Fett hunting Luke's friends across the galaxy is actually false. Boba Fett only worked alongside Darth Vader since he needed his help in capturing Han Solo in order to give him over to Jabba The Hutt. Darth Vader on the other hand was hunting Luke's friends since they were rebels and he needed them in order to lure Luke into a trapWhile I do love this movie I don't think it is the greatest Star Wars movie of all time or the best in the entire Original Trilogy. Quite frankly, it's a little overrated. Is it awesome? Yes. But the greatest or the best? Absolutely not.

reviews.heading: The best one in the classic trilogy

reviews.content: Those not born around the time of Star Wars have no clue how Star Wars impacted cinema and created the "blockbuster". So much of pop culture changed once Star Wars came out it was insane, from toys, magazine articles, music, media coverage, video games (eventually), and dance clubs (disco was huge).Three years later came Empire Strikes Back and while it was a better film (imo) it wasn't as loved (by critics and movie goers though less by critics) it was still amazing. Out of the three films, Empire has clearly aged the best and has become probably the fan favorite of all the films (including the prequels/sequels). There isn't much I can add to the long debate and what has already been said, but I can add another voice to the discussion surrounding Empire.The biggest reveal that Empire brought was the revelation surrounding Darth Vader and Luke but for those seeing it for the first time today it will have little impact as it will probably already be known. Even so, Empire offers so much more than Star Wars had including bigger battles, Lando, Boba Fett & bounty hunters, better Darth Vader outfit, Luke learning about the force/introduction to Yoda, and Darth Vader being in charge. The tone of Empire was also much darker though today's audiences will probably not agree as other films under the Star Wars label will be more so.Overall, Empire Strikes back offers so much more than Star Wars and even some of the other films but for those of us who saw Star Wars in 1977 nothing will beat the experience of the original though Empire will always be my favorite.
reviews.heading: The Best of the Saga

reviews.content:
Watched as part of a Star Wars Marathon, hence the shorter review.This is it. This is the greatest Star Wars film, this is the quintessential sci-fi movie. It has everything: a strong, likeable cast of characters, an even stronger plot with zero dull moments, a beautiful musical score, innovation beyond belief, development of the universe with characters like Yoda and Lando, and one of the single most memorable twists in cinema history. It is to sci-fi what Terminator 2 is to action. All three acts - Hoth, Dagobah, and Cloud City - are a joy to watch. The set design is truly on another level when held up against not only Star Wars, but other films too. Characters have clear, satisfying development, changing relationships, and some are even permanently physically and mentally altered. If Episode 4 was the setup, it was worth it for this level of payoff - the film doesn't need to worry with exposition or closure. It's just iconic scene after iconic scene. This is a true cinema classic.86/100--Admin--
