reviews.content: As brilliant as "A New Hope" was this film takes it and raises the the bar. Darth Vader and the empire are in pursuit of the Falcon and Luke to strike a decisive blow into the rebellion. Luke goes off to train with an old Master Yoda before facing Vader. The fight and chase scenes are taken up a couple of notches from the the previous film with the Carbon freezing and Vader unveiling as Luke's father are still as iconic as ever. Its a magnificently constructed movie and earns its rightful place as one of the all time great movies.
reviews.heading: DO OR DO NOT, THERE IS NO TRY!!

reviews.content: This movie expands upon everything A New Hope creates, ups the stakes, and adds a layer of darkness, and an atmosphere of hopelessness that is almost unmatched.I'm incredibly serious when I say this may be the best sequel of all time, and it's certainly my favorite and what I think to be the best in the series.
reviews.heading: If not one of the best, certainly one of the most important movies of all time.

reviews.content: Of course, this is the best Star Wars movie ever, and the best Darth Vader version. A very enjoyable classic movie, with great epic events and music, as we are used to in the Star Wars atmosphere.
reviews.heading: A great classic movie (9.1/10)

reviews.content: The exciting story. The enthralling places. The captivating characters. The lively sounds. The overwhelming music. Not to mention the dark mood, the brooding feel, and the seriousness of it all -- hand in hand with the often quoted claim that "these are movies made for children". It all comes together in a maelstrom of pure movie magic. This is the pinnacle of "Star Wars". It goes straight to the heart... and then through it. It's an emotional bomb.To surpass this would take a miracle. Will it ever happen? I sure hope so. Because I definitely want more of this. (Believe it or not, but the animated series "The Clone Wars" comes close.)This is the standard that "Star Wars" should look to when charting its future journeys. It is proof that when "Star Wars" goes dark, "Star Wars" goes good.Seeing this movie, taking it all in, makes me sad. Not just because of the story, not just because of the nostalgia, but also because of the massive contrast it creates against the "Star Wars" of today. It's like two different worlds, two different realities.Of all the fleeting sights and sounds reverberating through the dark tunnel of time, this movie runs through it all.
reviews.heading: Best. Movie. Ever.

reviews.content: Best star wars movie of all times, i cannot see this movie and think of how disney permited itself to ruin the continuity of this saga.
reviews.heading: B.E.S.T

reviews.content: Welcome to another edition of Adam's Reviews!! **queue in intro music**"Adventure, excitement a Jedi craves not these things"Tonight's movie review is Star Wars Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980) where we find the evil Lord Darth Vader on the search for Luke Skywalker at any cost. The Empire are also at their most menacing after the events of the previous film where the Death Star was destroyed and are hunting down the Rebels. This chapter also continues the journey of young Luke Skywalker to become a Jedi.We start on the ice and snowy planet Hoth where Luke encounters a Wampa who captures him and ties him upside down in order to eat him. The gang are concerned and Han goes out looking for the missing Luke. Here we get to witness a glimpse of the Force and the "ghost" Force of Obi-Wan-Kenobi. Once Luke is rescued and taken back to the Rebel base, the planet is under threat by the Empire and soon a battle commences with the Rebels fighting with the Imperial AT-AT Walkers. The Walker machines themselves are so creatively made and give the extra punch to the battle.This film soon splits up the heroes where Luke and R2 travel to a distant swamp planet so Luke can receive further Jedi training from Master Yoda. The problem is, Yoda does not want to teach him how to become a Jedi, since he finds Luke extremely impatient and can sense Luke's anger similar to his father Anakin. Obi Wan tries to change Yoda's mind, but only when Luke promises to really gives his best, Yoda accepts the challenge. The training sequence with Luke and Master Yoda were excellent and epic. One of the greatest lines in the series are found in this film given by Yoda, "do or do not, there is no try."The Degobah set is just one of the best sets ever. It looks like a real environment. It's dirty, slimy and foggy and makes you wonder why Yoda would ever want to live there in the first place. Luke has this dark vision of himself battling Vader, which is a vision of the future that might happen and kills Vader and sees himself in the helmet, just before it explodes.Meanwhile, Han, Leia, Chewie and C3PO are on the run and with the Falcon's hyperdrive broken, they are chased by the Empire's Tie Fighter. The gang are also trying to escape Imperial battleships and use different manoeuvres including flying through asteroid fields. We see Han's pilot capabilities including hiding in one of the asteroid rocks which happened to be a giant alien creature's stomach. Han Solo and Princess Leia maintain the personalities that they developed in New Hope and we get to see a love/hate relationship between the two of them, where neither one of them wants to admit their feelings for the other. This romantic subplot is characterized perfectly and both actors have the chemistry to show their feelings for each other grow more and more as the film progresses.Darth Vader is defs badass evil in this film which can be demonstrated with his lack of patience for failure among his fleet. Yeppp the scene where he force chokes those who fail him one after the other. He promotes an imperial guard to a higher rank and there's just this look of fear on this guard's face.So manyyyy things happen in this film, we get see Lando Calrissian, a smuggler who is looking after the people on Cloud City and an old acquaintance of Solo and Chewie. We get to see Bobba Fett and Vader together, we see the Emperor in a Hologram talking to Darth Vader and towards the end of the film we have the startling revelations which reveals the origins of young Skywalker. The scene when Solo is about to be carbon frozen and we see Leia taking the chance to let emotions go with providing cheesy romantic moment by saying 'I love you' just before Han is lowered into the freezing chamber, and he saves the moment by responding, "I know"....chillss...typical Han Solo way.The movie from start to end was mind blowing, the direction is creative, the characters feel real, the nature of the Force is explored more without losing its mysticism and the pacing is fast and more intense than its predecessor. Darker and more mature with great effects for an 80's movie, appealing characters and lots of spellbinding action. The storyline is tighter, and goes much deeper into character development. The performances are terrific, especially by Harrison Ford and Billy Dee Williams. The scenes between Luke and Yoda are just timeless along with the lightsabre duel between Darth Vader and Luke Skywalker, which is truly one of the most suspenseful and dramatic scenes in the entire saga. Overall 8.6/10.
reviews.heading: Do or do not - there is no try

reviews.content: This film is truly a masterpieces. It deserves all the praise it already receives and should continue to receive praise.Everything is amazing; the music, the VFX, the plot, the music, the cinematography, the pacing............ Did I mention the music?Everything that was great about the first movie, it's even better in this one. The dialogue is actually decent for once. Dialogue has always been a problem with the Star Wars franchise.The base plot is that the Rebellion are evacuating Hoth because the Empire have tracked down their hidden base. Then once the Rebels narrowly escape the rest of the movie is basically a really long car chase but in space. Also Luke gives Yoda a piggy back.
reviews.heading: The peak of filmmaking

reviews.content: I always ask others which Star Wars movie was their favorite. Most say Return of the Jedi because of its climactic ending, and although I can't argue with them at all, my pick is Empire Strikes Back.This movie accurately conveys the power the Empire has over the Rebellion and the many daring and courageous feats the Rebellion must be forced to go through in order to achieve not just victory, but survival. The acting again in this movie is second to no other space drama, very mature and makes you feel the realism in the story. The battles depicted are somewhat futile for the rebels as you feel throughout the story that the mighty Empire is just closing in on our beloved characters, culminating in the loss of Han and Luke's hand.The maturity continues in the relationships between Han and Leia, Luke and Yoda and Darth Vader. The comical love/hate relationship Han and Leia have blossoms into this yearning Leia has for Han to be more and this yearning for Han for Leia to love him for who he is. It becomes evident that although they don't share their feelings for each, there is a connection there that builds into a longing to see them together. The master and the student relationship between Yoda and Luke builds on the teachings of Obi-Wan and the Luke's recklessness as all students at one point or another show. And finally the relationship between Darth Vader and the viewer. Whereas once you found yourself hating this figure, cheering and laughing watching him helplessly corkscrew off into space after Han saves Luke during Luke's Death Star run, to cringing at his ugly, scarred head in his chamber, you suddenly found yourself intrigued at the cliffhanger this movie leaves you in. He is evil personified, but suddenly flawed and you find yourself wondering what will become of him.It's such a dark movie. The good guy doesn't win here. There is no celebration at the end. It leaves you in agony. For me, having to wait another 3 years to find out what will become of everyone. Will or Can the rebels really win? By the end of this movie, I wasn't really sure.Enough can't be said about the soundtrack for the movie. The way John Williams made you feel with the different themes used and the background of each scene. You felt the Imperial Walkers in the music. The swashbuckling sounds of the Millenium Falcon in the asteroid field. Darth Vader's theme expresses that military might that only a superpower can embody and Yoda's theme makes you feel and understand the spirituality of the Force. All brilliantly wrapped up in the main theme and expressed beautifully in the end credits.This is my favorite Star Wars movie of all time. I can't say that Jedi isn't a close second, but the way this movie made me feel way back when and the edge of my seat longing for the 3rd movie to tell me what the hell will happen to everybody will always make me feel that this was without a doubt the best sequel of all time.
reviews.heading: The Best Star Wars Movie Of All Time

reviews.content: I saw "Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back" in the the theater. I saw the "Special Edition" in the theater too. I've seen it many times at home. Every time I watch "The Empire Strikes Back" I remember how the audience reacted. I remember when they laughed and I remember when they cheered. Few movies can bring be back to the theater experience like this movie. I don't watch "The Empire Strikes Back" as much as I watch the original Star Wars but I still have seen it a bunch of times. It's always an easy watch.
reviews.heading: Solid sequel

reviews.content:
By far BEST STAR WARS MOVIE. Luke's journey
from a farm boy to a jedi is what makes it so good and Han and Lea's love story on the other hand finishes it. DARTH VADER = BEST VILLAIN.
reviews.heading: Ive got a gooood feeling about this.

reviews.content: Its a really cool film I can recommend it to you If you like smth like that.
reviews.heading: good film

reviews.content: This sequel to the first Star Wars - (whoops, Ep 4) was even better. Again I don't consider Star Wars original, there are SO many sci-fi tropes its ripped off. But it made science fiction go mainstream and the rising tide lifted all the boats - too bad they were mired in the "New Wave" and didn't know enough to get out of it in time to feed the public wanting Adventure sci-fi.I think this is the best of the original trilogy but all are top notch.
reviews.heading: A darker tone - epic plot twist

reviews.content: There is a reason that this movie is often regarded as the greatest movie sequel of all-time! Because this is all that A New Hope is, but times ten! There's more action, somehow more worldbuilding, and the characters are even more likable than in the first movie. All I can really say is that this is the best overall film of any Star Wars movie to date!9/10.
reviews.heading: An Exceptional Sequel!

reviews.content: I am not the biggest fan of A New Hope, but The Empire Strikes Back took me completely by surprise! I loved the action and twists and new settings featured in this one, and was surprised when the full length of the movie flew by. Han and Leia's romance is definitely a little dated (still iconic) but overall I don't have any real complaints with this movie. A great time!
reviews.heading: A great sequel!

reviews.content: So I decided to review the 3 Star Wars movies, all with the same review. Just because the last movies are horrible for me. So I will copy paste the same review. Star Wars is just the best movie for me. I was a kid when I first saw this... Wow... I dreamed about it, I was reading the 300+ page books, I played the video games etc. I played the music so many times... So it is not honest now to review the movie, I have no clear mind.My father said: it is just a fairy tale it is not so much. Maybe he is right, but I can never change my mind and watch Star Wars with a clear mind. But I must say later on I had some questions about the story an for me there is too much talking in the second movie. And I do like to watch the old versions, with the polished up versions the special effects are looking more fake because of the higher quality. But I still ike they did it, my daughter is liking it also. It is nice to see it can still make an impact on children these days.
reviews.heading: This is not a honest review

reviews.content: 'Star Wars: Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back' has it easier on the one hand, since the basic characters and the basic story can be taken for granted. On the other hand, the sequel is automatically compared with the predecessor and the pressure of expectation is high.Episode V doesn't need to hide from its predecessor. On the contrary, it's even a bit better. The main reason for this is that the aforementioned basic elements no longer need to be introduced. This episode can deal with new things and, above all, a deeper story right from the beginning.Starting with the battle on the ice planet Hoth. This is really good and can convince with the effects. The mood is altogether more threatening, darker and a bit more brutal. This part seems more serious and adult than Episode IV, but the funny and easy undertone of the characters is still not lost. This is mainly due to Han Solo, C3PO and R2-D2.We also learn more about Darth Vader and Yoda appears on the scene (again). Yoda is one of the best characters, but I find him in the first scenes when Luke meets him like a senile, not serious, slightly stoned weirdo.Overall, a successful continuation and an ideal starting point for the conclusion of the first trilogy.
reviews.heading: Great successor

reviews.content: This film is great, I think it's the best sequel ever. Firstly, the plot is awesome, it has the greatest plot twist in cinema's history. Some moments are very funny, but some of them make you cry. Secondly, yhe cast is amazing, but my favourite is Harisson Ford. I really likeiky Master Yoda, he is so cute in old trilogy. Thirdly, the action and visual effects look outstanding, but they are made without computer technology.So, it's one of greates Sci-Fi movie ever.
reviews.heading: The best sequel ever

reviews.content: There is nothing to comment, it is the best of the saga.
reviews.heading: Best Star Wars Movie

reviews.content: Still the best of the series, Empire is a dark atmospheric movie with so much going for it. The characters we knew to love in the first movie have more dimensions now and newcomers add to the mix. And of course that ending...
reviews.heading: Still the best

reviews.content: This movie is an example of how to not only do a perfect sequel, but a perfect sci-fi movie in general.
reviews.heading: Greatest Star Wars Best Movie

reviews.content: The empire strikes back is probably one of the most iconic movies ever made. Everyone knows Vader's "I am your father" line or "Do or do not, there is no try". And the reason the movie is the most iconic of the Star Wars saga, is because it's the consensus best of the Star Wars saga. It's not my personal favorite but I will agree that there is definitely an argument for it to be the best. I don't think it's a perfect 10, and if I could give it a 9.5 I would.
reviews.heading: Empire strikes back

reviews.content: From start to finish it's an incredible film and really shows and pushes the boundaries of filmmaking from the era it was made. The way they do all the visual/special effects is insane and looks so beautifully well done.
reviews.heading: A masterclass of Cinema and Sci-fi fantasy

reviews.content: This is a great movie, especially for it's time. I think the overall character line up of this film was nearly as good as A New Hope, as whilst Obi-Wan still made some appearances he wasn't in this nowhere near as much as A New Hope, though Yoda in this film makes up for that a lot. The lightsaber duel between Vader and Luke in this was much more better than the duel between Obi-Wan and Vader in A New Hope so it's definitely far better than a New Hope on that. This film has many great parts such as the Dagobah part and some of the spaceship parts in this (particularly the asteroid field part) were pretty entertaining.The romance in this movie had a lot of emotion and chemistry in it, The romance added another ark to the tension between Han and Luke as they were both competing for Leia's affection so I found that quite interesting and complex. Overall this film is the 5th best Star Wars movie for me and the 71st best film for me.A lot of people put this film first or second on their list of best Star Wars films but I feel a lot of people do that because they watched Star Wars saga for the first time in non-chronological order and instead by release date which would make that big reveal at the end more memorable and emotional for them. The problem with rating a movie based on shock value is because the shock or surprises a film has only really does that on the first viewing so yes if you watched Empire Strikes Back before the Prequels then that scene would be very shocking but I don't tend to include shock value in my rating as a lot of people watch a film more than once. Besides I think watching the films in chronological order (starting with TPM) is better and more shocking, seeing Anakin become Vader, chopping Windu's hand off, as a person who watched the Prequels before the Originals I think that scene was more shocking on first viewing than what it would be if I had watched the bit where Vader reveals he's Luke's father in Empire Strikes Back before the Prequels.The first 30-35 minutes of this film were somewhat boring for me, there just wasn't much interesting complex things happening all it was was Vader simply finding the Rebel's secret base on Hoth and most of it was just mindless boring basic action involving a spaceship battle (though the bit with the yeti like monster and some lines Han said were quite good). The rest of the film though is what makes this film truly great. The Empire Strikes Back is also the only Original trilogy film which has bits of truly great scenery as I really liked the look of Cloud City, the rest of the scenery though (with a mild exception for Dagobah) was pretty drab and dull I think.The Vader scenes where Vader seemed to be hesitant to violently face his son and tried his best to convince the Emperor to spare him I felt were pretty interesting and emotional. I also really liked the bits where Obi-Wan and Yoda are hesitant to train Luke because they see too much of Anakin in Luke which I felt was a great way to really connect Luke and Anakin and I always felt that Yoda probably wouldn't have accepted Luke being further trained in the force if Yoda and Obi-Wan weren't so desperate to defeat the Emperor.
reviews.heading: A masterpiece after the first 35 minutes

reviews.content: This is the greatest most exciting Star Wars movie ever. This has the first appearance of Boba Fett(My 2nd favorite character) who is awesome. There is lots of great things about this movie.
reviews.heading: Best Star Wars Movie

reviews.content: I'm not afraid to say that this is the best Star Wars movie. A classic, with the most incredible plot twist of all. it's official: this film is timeless!
reviews.heading: The best!

reviews.content: That statement alone could stir up controversy, with some saying that that title belongs to THE GODFATHER, PART II or THE DARK KNIGHT. While I agree that those sequels rank the best, I would still have to give the crown to THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK. It's marvelous! Energetic, funny, thrilling, dark and complex; it has everything for the audience to enjoy! There is not ONE slow moment; moving at the speed of a particular Corellian freighter through light speed without sacrificing any character development or story progression! Not just a perfect sequel, it's a perfect film! ESB just celebrated its 40th anniversary, and still feels so fresh! May the Force continue to be with the best sequel ever made!
reviews.heading: The best sequel ever made!

reviews.content: Such an exceptional film. It's amazing that these were made decades ago but are still jaw-dropping. I was totally missing out on the Star Wars universe.
reviews.heading: Can't believe it took me this long to watch it

reviews.content: Luke Skywalker, Han Solo, Princess Leia and Chewbacca face the attack of the imperial forces and their AT-AT walkers on the ice planet Hoth. While Han and Leia escape on the Millennium Falcon, Luke travels to Dagobah in search of Yoda. Only with the help of Jedi Master Luke will he survive when the Dark Side of the Force calls him to the final duel with Darth Vader.

This film is so great. It works on so many levels and the best sequel of all time. Who doesn't love this movie if is well shot, great characters and everything is just 10 times better than the original. Star Wars is still to this day one of the greatest films ever made and I didn't think it could get better. I was wrong.
reviews.heading: Behold the Legend Itself

reviews.content: I could do a long review detailing how every part of this movie is brilliantly made and executed but l its easier just to say this movie is the greatest most perfect film made
reviews.heading: Perfection

reviews.content:
It's just a classic filmI see it as often as I did. The Trilogy was the first VHS I ever owned. My point is that emotional attachment, or detachment to a film is equally important to what a person may think of it critically as a piece of art, or entertainment.I have loved all the Star Wars films and have seen them all except for the first one on its opening day and even the first show of that day with the last two! All that said however, I wouldn't call any of them "great films". Important and amazing films, "Hell Ya!". Some of the best rides I have ever had, "Hell Ya!".Worth watching all in a row every now and again, you bet. Episode V is more of a love story and character developing episode IV which is why it tends to be many folks favorite thus far. Knowing it will be a blast and finding out that Vader is really
Luke's dads only bolsters it.I think Jedi is the best still and part of that may be the fact that I knew that Blue Harvest was really Star Wars III (episode VI) when they shot all the wonderful "forest" scenes. I didn't watch them do it, but knowing it was happening and that the speeder chases were truly impossible (since I lived and played Star Wars in those woods), yet there they were right in front of my eyes. This may be why it still has the strongest hold on my heart! I don't think that the story of Jedi significantly better than Empire
reviews.heading: classic film!

reviews.content: Everything about this sequel was just better in every category compared to the last flim. The story was well written and was executed nicely.The pacing of this movie was good it had a slow start but a great finish. Great acting, dialogue, chereography. and good CGI. Luke's development in this flim was amazing to see and the dynamic between Han and Leia was nicely written also.Overall a flim that I had mixed feelings about but still enjoyable to say the least.
reviews.heading: A good sequel..

reviews.content: Disney-led, CGI-rich episodes hit the bottom since they missed the point.They thought that throwing a ton of FX at us together with bringing back the original actors would make for the absent story.Sadly for all of us, it was never just about that.Empire Strikes Back leads as the best space movie because it managed to land a rock-solid story that still stays with us in exactly the same way it was delivered 41 years ago.And it clearly proves that the ESB makers next to the money, which justly was the purpose of making it, they also had the capacity to blow their own passion into it.Kudos to that.
reviews.heading: It's the story, stupid

reviews.content: The sequel to the original Star Wars feels like it could be longer. Although, The sets and the action are even better than A New Hope. The Battle of Hoth is an epic and cinematic sequence that shows the creativity of the filmmakers. It will always be cringey to me because I am used to modern film, but even though the original trilogy released in the 80s it is fun to watch and experience the innovation.
reviews.heading: Hoth

reviews.content:
The cultural and technological significance of The Empire Strikes Back speaks for itself. It revolutionised CGI and practical effects to a whole new level.
The characters are so good, no wonder why they're so iconic. Everything points to the director having an idea of the characters created: Yoda's monologue about the force is so beautiful, it embodies the love Yoda has for it. And Han Solo's "I know" is so to character, keeping that arrogant and boastful persona as he would.
The use of the force is the epitome of subtlety as it creates this beautiful living organism.
It's a cinematic masterpiece: where the CGI might not hold up today, the cinematography certainly does, clearly inspiring movies to come.
Obviously it's one of the greatest action movies, let alone movies in total.
For some reason I prefer A New Hope
reviews.heading: It's Star Wars, you know how good it is

reviews.content:
Pros: this movie is better than the original in everyway... the actors show more, the action has tension and suspense instead of being fun and fast paced, The music is the best in the franchise, every character from the first is expanded upon and the new characters are fleshed out really well too.
It's dark, sad and better than the first
reviews.heading: An improvement in every way

reviews.content: Terrific, again.'The Empire Strikes Back' follows up on the greatness of 'Star Wars' with a highly enjoyable sequel. This one feels like a big moment in the franchise, at least to someone who doesn't know what's upcoming, as we get sizeable moments alongside some cool character reveals.Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher continue to impress in their respective roles, as does James Earl Jones. Elsewhere, Billy Dee Williams and Frank Oz make for strong additions. There are, once again, fun roles for Anthony Daniels, Peter Mayhew and Kenny Baker.I'd say its predecessor has aged better - though that's not to say this film looks even the slightest bit bad, as it still looks fantastic throughout. The plot is as great as before, as is everything else really - namely the music, for one.I think I prefer the 1977 film over this, but there's barely anything separating the two in my thoughts to be honest. Both are awesome!
reviews.heading: Terrific, again

reviews.content:
This review is for the 1980 theatrical release and not the 1997 and later specialized editions.This movie really did push movie making when it was released in 1980. The special effects, performances and story are breath taking. It doesn't look too much to existing myths for inspiration but rather in creating its own lore. It takes the Force, the darkside, the lightside, the Jedi and explores them and expands on them to make a more deeper film. Yet it still maintains a sense of humor.
The film has aged remarkably well, it is a beautiful movie from start to finish. While the original Star wars may have revolutionized cinema, the Empire Strikes Back perfected it. It proved that pop culture can be every bit as good as any drama or period piece. I wouldn't hesitate to put it as a contender as the greatest movie ever made. That is not a guarantee everyone will like it, but it deserves everyones respect.
reviews.heading: How sequels should be done

reviews.content:
I love this part very much because of the Lando and a twist in Solo's destiny.
And there is Yoda here!
And I love the last minute of screenplay when they are standing and watching out of the window. This is the shot that I always remember when I think of them.The actors and the movie crew must be proud of effect they put on kids (and adults) of 70-90s. I had unique childhood, the best - thanks to Star Wars!
reviews.heading: Very important in trilogy and well-done

reviews.content: A masterpiece....difficult to improve on A New Hope yet it does....very rarely watch a movie more than once...,,amongst those exceptions are Lawrence of Arabia, Blade Runner and a New Hope (around 5 times each).....and then, The Empire Strikes Back, 21 times.
reviews.heading: In the top 10 best movies ever made

reviews.content: As a kid I was never interested in star wars, for one reason or another i just never watched any of the movies. It was until 10 years later when i was 17 years old, that i was visiting my grandparents for the day and i decided to watch some cable, I came across a star wars marathon, it happened to be the final battle of Ep 1, where Darth maul fights Quigon and kenobi, i was spellbound. I was blown away by star wars that i didn't change the channel and i decided to watch the rest of the 6 movie saga in one night. My life was forever changed that day. Recently I decided to have a star wars marathon, and give an up to date review of the 6 movies.The Story: After the destruction of the death star, the empire is determined to find and destroy the rebellion, and Darth vader has special interest in finding Luke skywalker, to turn him to the dark side. After an extraordinary battle on the ice planet of hoth, the rebellion are now on the run, with Han, Leia and chewbacca being mercilessily chased by the empire. Meanwhile Luke is told by the ghost of his old mentor, ben kenobi to travel to an obscure planet to find an ancient jedi master named Yoda, to complete his training as a jedi knight. Despite yodas best efforts, luke is still not ready, which complicates things, when his friends are captured by the empire, and he decides to go rescue them, defying yoda and kenobis advice. What proceeds, is the most impactful confrontation in all of fiction. With luke having a lightsaber duel with Darth vader, and ending with vader revealing that he is lukes long lost father. If there is a person alive who doesn't know this spoiler than i would be surprised, even i knew about the" I Am Your father " way before watching it, but i will say every time i see it i am amazed and shocked by this impressive plot twistThe Characters: Luke is far more mature in this movie, but can still be reckless, despite his efforts to be trained by yoda, he chooses to save his friends over his much needed training, and is handed his ass by vader, which humbles luke and puts him back on the path to being a powerful jedi with experience. Darth vader is also given a lot of development in this film, instead of being the faceless big bad, we understand he is a servant to an even greater evil, but we are reminded that vader is ruthless and not to be trusted, which is what makes his reveal to luke seem questionable. Despite this you can feel his disappointment when luke refuses to join him, and that he is not the emotionless monster we all believed him to be. The rejection of his own son could have very well awakened anakin within him, and in fact it is luke that creates the potential for vaders redemption. Han is shown to be just as smug as ever, as he tries to gain the affection of leia throughout the movie, but it is his love for his friends and leia that make him so much more than a scruffy looking nerf herder. Leia is quite aggressive in this movie, mostly towards Han, but that could be because she has repressed feelings for him, that she doesnt not want to acknowledge since it might bring down her authority, but as we all know love makes you stronger. lando Calrissian has to be the smoothest talker in this galaxy, and despite his betrayal, he is still likeable, which is why its a relief when he helps the heroes in the end. Boba Fett doesn't have many lines, but his mere presence is spine tingling, and being the first Mandalorian on screen is quite impressive. Yoda is goofy and cute at first, he then makes the transition to the wise grandmaster of the jedi we know and love, never once is the illusion shattered for me, by his puppetry work, instead i believe he is a living breathing creature.The Action: The battle of hoth is quite impressive, with the walkers, space fighters, and ground troops all creating an amazing action sequence that is both energetic and immersive. The millennium Falcon chase, can seem quite long, but there is so much done with it, such as going through an asteroid field, that it contributes to the adventure aspect of the film. While the lightsaber fight is not as energetic or as spectacular as the ones seen in the prequels or clone wars tv show, this fight is still well choreographed, with vader also using a lot of force powers during the fight, as well as a lot of suspense being included with Luke being hopelessly outclassed. All the effects from the creature to the lightsabers, are highly better in this movie than the first, and it really makes you feel that this is a real galaxy.The legacy: This is without a doubt the best star wars movie that not only gives the audience a good dose of action, adventure, romance, and wonder, it is also the movie that defined star wars. Yoda educating luke about the force is both profound and engrossing, and is probably what helps lead to the grand expanded universe of star wars that makes it one of the most unique works of science fiction ever. Allowing star wars to be so much more than just the movies, and why it affects so many people, past, present, and future. The training scenes with yoda are compelling, the action is enthralling, the romance between Han and leia is great, the build up of luke and vaders confrontation is full of tension, and the reveal always leaves me in awe. This movie will forever be timeless and touch everyone's heart who see's it. In the end, this movie is Impressive, Most Impressive.
reviews.heading: The Masterpiece that Defined Star wars: Deep Analysis

reviews.content: When George Lucas was asked which was the worst Star Wars film, he responded with 'The Empire Strikes Back', one of the only original films from the saga that he did not direct. Episode 5 was proven to not be the worst episode and instead, was rather flattered by the critics, gaining 94% on Rotten Tomatoes and 8.7/10 on IMDb. The ensemble cast is carried over from The first film released 3 years before Episode 5, 'A New Hope' and produces a thrilling encounter of the Rebellion' resurrection. It is evident that the titles are almost back and forth for the Rebellion's sake, whenever a title is in their favour, the next Episode pushes them back. It has been 3 years since the destruction of the Death Star and the Rebel Alliance, led by Princess Leia, has set up a new base on the ice planet Hoth, a desolate, low-temperature, snow-blizzard land. The Imperial fleet, led by merciless Darth Vader, hunts for the new Rebel base by dispatching probe droids across the Galaxy. Luke Skywalker, struggling to control himself in the cold, is captured by a wampa while investigating one such probe. He finds himself tied up, hanging from above in a dark cage, the newly named Jedi is able to escape by using the Force and his lightsaber. Before Luke succumbs to hypothermia, the Force spirit of his deceased mentor, Obi Wan Kenobi, instructs him to go to the swamp planet Dagobah to train under Jedi Master Yoda. Han Solo discovers Luke and keeps him alive by keeping him under the body fat of his dead Tauntaun mount, and the two are rescued by a search party the following morning. Luke as clearly matured in the three years he has been present in the Rebellion, and he see his character develop throughout. Being more independent, wiser and learning to take matters into his own hands, moulding into the Jedi that Obi Wan formerly was. The probe alerts the Imperial fleet to the Rebel's location . The Empire launches a large-scale attack using AT-AT walkers to capture the base, it was admitted that scenes featuring the large walkers took the longest to film, reasoning their slow and lethargic movements. The Rebels manage to evacuate, Han and Leia escape with C-3PO and Chewbacca on the Millennium Falcon, but the ship's hyperdrive malfunctions. They hide in an asteroid field, where Han and Leia grow closer amidst the tensions, the pair seem to attract quite easily to one another. Several Bounty Hunters, summoned by Vader, assist in searching for the the Falcon. Meanwhile, Luke travels with R2-D2 in his X-Wing to Dagobah where he crash-lands in the middle of an eerie swamp. The X-Wing used by Luke is named AA-59 and is a T-65B model. The star fighter is armoured with 4 laser cannons, 2 proton torpedo launchers and 6 proton torpedoes (crucial in the act of destroying the Death Star), weighing 110kg its class 1 hyperdrive rating allows it to be extremely flexible, fitting into narrow spaces. Luke meets with a diminutive creature whilst first plays with young Skywalker, joking around him and confusing him with his distinctive speech. He later reveals himself as Yoda, who reluctantly accepts Luke as his apprentice after conferring with Obi Wan's spirit. We visualise for the first time, the wise Jedi legend Yoda, who appears unique in his aspects. His small frame supports him as a Jedi, with his low space tee of gravity proving for good balance. His wrinkled face is deceiving to the Sith at first, but inside him is a ruthless nature. His wisdom of the Force is beyond any other Jedi, his experience manifests this. The character itself is a puppet, performed by Frank Oz who also supplies his voice, Oz is also the puppeteer behind the famous Miss Piggy, from 'The Muppets'. Luke learns more about the force from Yoda, who lifts his X-Wing out of the swamp using the power of the Force. After evading the Imperial fleet, Han's group travels to the floating Cloud City on the planet Bespin, which is governed by Han's old friend Lando Calrissian. Bounty Hunter Boba Fett, son of Jango, tracks the Falcon and, with Vader, forces Lando to hand the group over to the Empire. Boba is similar to Jango apart from his improved suit design, he aims to continue his father's legacy as a Bounty Hunter, and has a personal hatred toward the Jedi, following Jango's decapitation from Mace Windu. Vader plans to use the group as bait to lure Luke, intending to capture him and turn him to the dark side of the Force. Luke experiences a premonition of Han and Leia in pain, Yoda explains to him the importance of patience and that learning the ways of the Force takes time to master, against his and Obi Wan's wishes, Luke abandons his training to rescue them. Vader intends to hold Luke in suspended animation by imprisoning him in carbonate, selecting Han to be frozen as trial experiment, this, much to Chewbacca's discontent, taking his anger out on Lando. Han survives the process and is given to Fett, who plans to collect a bounty on him from Jabba the Hutt. The term Bounty Hunter originates from South Africa, coming from the search for HMS Bounty, the famous ship captained by William Bligh that mutinies in April 1789. This could infer to Boba Fett's armour, embodying the traditional South African colours of green and yellow. Lando, still loyal to Han, frees Leia and Chewbacca, but they are too late to stop Fett from departing with Solo. Under attack from numerous stormtroopers, they fight their way back to the Falcon and flee the city. Meanwhile, Luke arrives and engages Vader in a tense lightsaber duel that leads them to the city's central air shaft, Vader appearing more defensive than offensive. Vader severs Luke's right arm, significant as the same happened to Anakin when in combat with Dooku. After Darth Vader disarms the young Jedi, he tempts him to embrace his anger and join the Dark side of the Force. Luke reiterates Obi Wan's telling, accusing the Sith Lord of murdering his father, metaphorically speaking that is true. Vader reveals that he is Luke's father, in 'four words' best known to the film. Horrified, Luke drops into the air shaft and is ejected beneath the floating city, hanging from an antenna. In a mixture of mental states, he reaches out telepathically to Leia, who senses him and persuades Lando and Chewy to turn back. After Luke is brought aboard, they are chased by TIE fighters towards Vader on his Star Destroyer and finds out that the Falcon's hyperdrive has been tampered with, but the confident, intelligent droid R2-D2 reactivates it, allowing them to escape. Luke rejoins the Rebel fleet and his severed hand is replaced with a robotic prosthesis, just like his father's previously. Lando and Chewbacca begin their quest to save Han, as the other Rebels watch in unison as the Falcon departs. Episode 5 sees the first confrontation of Luke and his father, Darth Vader and makes for an exciting next chapter to how he, being the only accessible Jedi left, will go about defeating the evil Sith Lord. Leia and Han's relationship expands in the screenplay, but of course is cut short due to Vader's experiment involving the pilot. This situation isn't resolved in the film and supplies a strong costarring base for the next chapter. An incredibly directed film, shows the Rebel alliance growing stronger and replacing the former 'Republic', allowing it to compete with the Galactic Empire. Vader's truth is out and just like Palpatine, his quest to turn Luke to the Dark Side, is his priority.

reviews.content: While the child in me loves Return of the Jedi, the adult in me realizes that this installment of Star Wars is, in fact, the most well constructed film overall.It benefits from a razor sharp focus on character development and does that very well tied in with some of the usual Star Wars fun of force moves, space battles, interesting aliens, and laser swords, of course. UNLIKE the sequel films however, these elements are used as dressing added on top of a great story and one of the best reveals in film history.
reviews.heading: Best film of the series

reviews.content: Movie sequels are often seen as an attempt to cash in on the original, but The Empire Strikes Back is not one of them. The films could also have been made as a retread of Star Wars, but it wasn't. Instead, it was designed to move the saga along.After the events of Star Wars, Han Solo, Princess Leia, Luke Skywalker and company are stationed on the snowy planet Hoth. Unfortunately, Darth Vader and the empire track them down and launch an attack on them. The rebels flee the planet. Luke enters the planet Dagobah, while the rest of the crew deal with TIE fighters and asteroids before reaching Bespin, where they meet Lando Calrissian (Billy Dee Williams). On Dagaboh, Luke meets Yoda who trains him to become a Jedi.The Empire Strikes Back is an excellent movie sequel that is actually better than the original. Not only does it move the story along, but we are treated with a twist regarding the truth about Darth Vader.
reviews.heading: Excellent Star Wars sequel

reviews.content: I can't imagine how painful it would have been to hear Chewbacca in theatres. Painful!
reviews.heading: So annoying and painful.

reviews.content: Forty years ago, in a galaxy far away. A sequel of the movie that changed cinema forever was made, and it sure as heck didn't failed on anyone.Every top best sequels I see always has Empire Strikes Back on the number one spot, and there's a reason why. It took many dark turns that nobody at the time saw coming, it didn't use the same elements that the previous movie used and it felt like we were exploring the galaxy a lot more than we did in the last film.If I have to pick where to put this on my Star Wars rank list, it'd be on the top three, just not sure where in the three spots.The romance part of the film works really well with Leia and Han. Sure, the age gap between Carrie and Harrison was a bit awkward, but they somehow made it work great for the franchise and became one of the best couples ever.The reveal of Vader being the father wasn't a surprise to me when I first watched it, because I started watching the franchise with the prequels first in 2006 and knew what was happening.And I know this is going to cause a debate, but I think Yoda is a Muppet. It's not because of Frank Oz performing him, but it's because he feels like one to me. I feel like the Jim Henson company helped a little bit making him and there was an episode of Muppet Show where Luke, Chewie, R2 and 3PO was in and to me, that was a deal that Lucas and Henson made as a fair enough collab as a team. There's even some behind the scenes pictures that Jim, Kermit and Piggy were in. Think about that for a few minutes.This is without a doubt, one of the best sequels that was ever made and will always be forever. The force has always been strong with the franchise and fandom, and will forever more.
reviews.heading: One of THE best sequels ever made

I believe this is the movie that best showcases Mark Hamill, Carrie Fisher, and Harrison Ford's chemistry, as well, obviously, the best movie reveal of all-time (after Snape being revealed as the Half-Blood Prince, lol).

reviews.heading: Greatest star-crossed "lovers" in history

reviews.content: Empire Strikes Back has long been my favorite in the original trilogy. I remember going to see this when this was released theatrically as a little kid with my grandma. Empire is one of the rare cases where the sequel blows away the original. Creator George Lucas got some very good help in making this with writer Lawrence Kasdan and hiring a director that actually knows what he was doing, Irvin Kershner. With outsourcing some good help, this collaboration turned out to being a winning team to bring (and improve upon) George Lucas's vision. The film looks incredible to this day and the groundbreaking special effects from the 1st film are improved upon and look better here. The story in this installment is darker(and better suited to my tastes), but is also stronger and better as a whole. The characters are better fleshed out then the original film, the chemistry between the actors and performance are also much better. Not only is Empire Strikes Back the best in the series, but I also would argue that it's the foundation on which the franchise continued to explode and why it holds up today.
reviews.heading: The best in the series

reviews.content: This has everything in the first movie - the visuals, story etc. BUT. It has loads and loads of plot twists, which makes the movie so, so interesting. Almost everyone would agree that it's the best Star Wars movie. Go watch it. Now.
reviews.heading: The best...

reviews.content: The second Star Wars movie ever made, "The Empire Strikes Back" is on par with the franchise's first installment as a piece of cinema, but it simultaneously sky rocketed the universe to new, fantastical heights.A logical sophomore chapter in the hero's journey, "Empire" starts roughly three years after the events of "A New Hope". Luke Skywalker, Han Solo, Princess Leia, Chewbacca, C-3PO, and R2-D2 are stationed on a rebel base on the snowy planet of Hoth - filmed on the blizzardous glaciers of Norway. But after the Galactic Empire attacks the base, everyone must flea.Han, Chewy, the Princess, and CPO all engage in a gripping chase across the galaxy that leads them through an asteroid field and into Cloud City on the planet Bespin. Here we meet Lando Calrissian (Billy Dee Williams), Han's old smuggler friend and a new addition to the franchise's iconic gang.Meanwhile, Luke and R2 head for a swampy planet on the Dagobah System, searching for Yoda - the Jedi who once trained Obi-Wan. Rather than being a human, though, Yoda is a two-foot tall green alien being. He speaks out of order and carries a quirky kind of sagacity that is nonsensical at first, but latently brilliant.Yoda is one of the most convincing cinematic puppets to date. Make up artist Stuart Freeborn designed him and Sesame Street veteran Frank Oz brings him to life with faultless movement and an iconic voice. The character is a pure manifestation of how "The Empire Strikes Back" ups the ante from its predecessor. In this movie, we get one of the wisest characters in film history, and he comes in the form of groundbreaking special effects.Beyond the heartwarming Yoda, "Empire" also offers audiences vaster images of the galaxy. In addition to Norway's glaciers, all set pieces are captivating throughout. From Yoda's swamp to Lando's city, every world has its own authentic energy. Moreover, the space scenes have improved from "A New Hope". With greater visual effects, the ships can be captured doing more spectacular stunts through the cosmos.The plot thickens from a character perspective as well. The love triangle between Luke, Han, and Leia grows more intense and the villainous Darth Vader becomes all the more interesting as we get our first glimpse at the Emperor himself through a hologram.We also learn a little something about Luke's family history that (even though the movie came out forty years ago and it is now the most referenced plot twist in popular culture) I will abstain from revealing here.There are countless other reasons that fans consistently point to "The Empire Strikes Back" as the best Star Wars movie to date. It is the first movie to feature Boba Fett; the first time we see the Force move an object without touching it; there is the Wampa yeti monster; the first light saber duel not to feature two old guys; and one of the most famous lines in movie history... again, I'm not spoiling anything...Much of the dialogue is a step up from the original, actually. This might have something to do with the fact that Lawrence Kasdan wrote the screenplay's final draft rather than George Lucas. The creator of Star Wars, Lucas served as executive producer on "Empire," but gave directorial reigns to Irvin Kershner.Because "A New Hope" has seniority on its side, "The Empire Strikes Back" cannot match the original's influence on cinema as a whole. However, it demonstrated that the first movie was not a fluke, that blockbusters can have good sequels, and that Star Wars offers a humungous imaginative canvas that we still explore to this day.
reviews.heading: Star Wars Strikes Back...Wonderfully

reviews.content: At least the original Star Wars had a story, with a beginning and an end.The sequel is nothing more than an action-filled instalment in a Saturday afternoon serial. How about anyone older than 12 enjoy this?But it has other problems. Luke is a simp. The more he's on screen the worse it gets. I'm surprised that in the three years between Star Wars and the sequel Lucas hadn't figured out that Hans Solo was the star. Frankly, I would have drop-kicked Princess Layover, too. She's so dull.And then when you think it can't get any worse, Fozzy Bear from the Muppets shows up wearing a little elfin costume and speaking with Yiddish syntax.And by the end it's obvious this was just a setup for the third one, but which time I would have figured everyone would have lost interest.
reviews.heading: Hard to believe the series survived this terrible movie

reviews.content: Was really excited to see this after seeing the first one and really wanted to like this... But sadly it's deminishing returns with retred elements from the first movie and relying too much on you having seen the previous one (a movie should stand on its own, that's why we have movies, tv shows and mini-series). The puppetry is amazing and practical effects are good, but the action is so lacklustre and definitely doesn't hold up. Too bad the movie is mostly dumb slapstick comedy and action.The western feeling or touch that was present in previous movie is gone and all you have is a "slapstick sitcom adventure" that feels like jumping in a middle of a filler tv show episode.The movie has dementia. Everything is show 2 times ie. Vader altering the deal, Darth Vader killing his co-workers for doing their job, hyperdrive going out of commission in crucial moments and Han (Harrison Ford) being suprised by that (3 times).You won't miss out on much, by not seeing this. Maybe only the performance by Frank Oz as Yoda (witch is really ingading and fun to watch)
reviews.heading: Sequels are hard, aren't they

reviews.content: Really high stakes and setting that aged very well. Better acting and action scenes this time, too.
reviews.heading: The Empire Strikes Back

reviews.content:
Star Wars : The Empire Strikes Back (1980) -
Brief Review ;-Star Wars strikes back with an Impossible Classic Sequel. Star Wars Episode IV was a mega blockbuster and the one of the most acclaimed film at its time so people kept very high expectations from the sequel. Logically, it was almost impossible to bring a sequel to such a high acclaimed film especially when you have to make it keeping in mind that you have to match the predecessor and also generate excitement for the next part. Then, Luacs Films brought The Empire Strikes Back and stunned the Star Wars fans again. A New Hope had sort of slow start because it had to introduce the characters but Episode V had an advantage that all the main characters were known so it begun on a blasting note. No further slow start, it begins directly with the explosions and does not stop it till the end. It was far more entertaining and less darker than the predecessor therefore enjoyment factors took over the show throughout the narrative. Empire Strikes introduced some interesting characters like Lando and Yoda yet it remained frontloaded. Harrison Ford looks so cute in this film, the additional humour in his character is Lovable. I loved seeing him flirting with the Princess. Oh my god, how gorgeous Carrie Fisher was looking as Leia but i didn't like the characterisation. She was supposed to have a solid sense of love but actually she was like you know fumbling, i mean she kissed Luke to make Han feel Jealous then confessed her love to Han and then she was fondly behaving with Luke again. Of course, we got the answers in the Sequel (Return Of The Jedi) but still it didn't make much sense here. Overall, The Empire Strikes Back delivered upto the expectations which is enough to call it, 'Arguably, the Best Sequel ever made'. There was no Lucas in director's chair but still Episode V scored merits, unbelievable.RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest
reviews.heading: The Star Wars strikes back with an Impossible Classic Sequel.

reviews.content: The second 'original' movie proved that you could make a high-budget film with puppets that had heft, tension and substance. It has only gained in beauty with time, and its visual effects are still impressive, despite being over 40 years old. Co-written by Lawrence Kasdan, the script is full of humour and drama. Kasdan would then go on to write several good Star Wars movies.
reviews.heading: Darker and more mature

reviews.content: This is the (in my Opinion) the the best of the Star Wars franchise ...... Love, Hate, Death, Rebirth .... it encompasses it all ... As far as the other movies are concerned (they have to FIX or manipulate) ... MEH ..
reviews.heading: Star Wars in it's Prime

reviews.content: To say this movie is overrated is just wrong. Not just in the sense of being incorrect. It's morally wrong to speak ill of this movie. This is more important than Picasso's work, or Da Vinci's or any other great artist. And to critique this film in any measure is perhaps the greatest display of a lack of self-awareness that a person is capable of. Who are we to question any aspect of the definitive masterpiece of all of human existence? Every technology breakthrough-from fire or the wheel, all the way to the computer or the internet-is merely a means to this end. If there were an asteroid aimed at annihilating all of human history, and we could only save one cultural artifact, it had dang well better be this movie. It represents the high point of human achievement. It is so mind bogglingly good that George Lucas should probably be etched in stone as his own version of Mt. Rushmore. His impact for good on the world through this movie is frankly incalculable. No human being will ever live on this planet without having been positively affected by it.
reviews.heading: The best movie ever made

reviews.content: A boyish perspective of the moments in life one must take to overcome grief, loss, and the thoughts that push us to be better people. Power corrupts youthful passion but is unable to stamp out hopes flame. Great film for anyone finding it difficult to find a purpose in life or something/someone to fight for.
reviews.heading: Why tropes don't matter in the hands of a master.

reviews.content: The film that solidified Star Wars' place in popular culture as a timeless franchise and shattered audience expectations like never before. Beginning the long-standing trend of a sequel darker and more mature than the first, the Empire Strikes Back takes everything the world adored about the first Star Wars (characters, story, score, themes, world building, etc.) and builds upon them in every way to craft a smart, daring and beloved improvement over its predecessor. Whatever has been said about this film already deserves to be repeated, because this film should and will stand throughout the ages.So many characters within this film that return from the original or are introduced for the first time are all-time fan favourites; Yoda, Boba Fett, the Emperor, Lando, Bossk, etc. The score is as magnificent and memorable as it can be, particularly the badass Imperial March that has become synonymous with evil. In the first film, the themes of hope and rebellion were strong and crowd-pleasing, but here, the audience is given a cold yet brilliant splash of water in their faces as they realise that actually, the bad guys sometimes win as the morals and goals of the heroes become more challenged than ever.So many scenes throughout the film are bound to stick in the back of your mind and never leave you for as long as you live because of how unique, iconic and well-written they are, from the speeders lassoing the legs of the walkers during the Battle of Hoth, to Yoda giving us a glimpse of just what the Force can accomplish by telekinetically lifting Luke's X-Wing out of Dagobah's swamp, to Han flying the Millennium Falcon out of the belly and through the jaws of a gigantic space worm inhabiting the asteroid they had hidden on, and of course, Darth Vader dropping a bombshell on Luke in a twist that shocked the world that remains the greatest scene in the whole franchise - "I am your father."The Empire Strikes Back is the reason so many people truly love Star Wars. It took a franchise already established to be filled with magic and improved it by creating a more mature and intriguing sequel that changed cinema as much as its predecessor. Nothing Disney or the saga's own creator has written since this film has been able to top this masterpiece and it seems like they never will. Whilst the first Star Wars (A New Hope) is the series' magnum opus (most important work), the Empire Strikes takes the throne and title as Star Wars at its greatest - a title that it has held undisputed ever since its release in 1980 and will most likely keep until the end of time.
reviews.heading: The Diamond Standard for Sci-Fi Epics

reviews.content: I could watch this many times and re-evaluate Luke Skywalker and Han Solo's character development. But I still think the original is probably the best. It's a debate that anyone who has seen all the Star Wars films could have any time. Even so, I thought this was a mesmerizing that held my attention from start to finish. It's also a great film about building up courage and fortitude for a challenge that lies ahead, specifically Skywalker's storyline in this film. Give me Darth Vader's best scenes in this film, give my Han Solo's best lines and Skywalker's training with Yoda and I'll tell you about a film for the ages. The Empire does strike back. And what a strike it is! Highly recommended
reviews.heading: Best Star Wars sequel, doesn't quite exceed the original

reviews.content: When I meet people who watched this already knowing the big reveal I pity them and explain how things used to be before the internet and spoilers became almost a sport.The secret that was contained in this film was an amazing cinematic experience for me and I have never had anything come close to it since. I was quite young at the cinema so maybe an older viewer could have seen it coming but I didn't and from the gasps in the audience, I'm guessing a lot of other people didn't see it coming either.Back the you would see friends the next day and tell they they have to see it but leave out the important details, now (mostly from the media trying to get an exclusive) its much harder to generate this kind of feeling.I am never a back in the old days things were better person But maybe just this once.Movies do not get better than The Empire Strikes Back
reviews.heading: I'm Your....Reviewer

reviews.content: This Star Wars movie was the darkest film with quality characters. In this film you get to know the characters properly. I love the interaction between Han Solo and Princess Leia, as well as many other great characters that are introduced and developed further.
reviews.heading: Best Star Wars movie ever!

reviews.content: This movie expands on everything the first movie does. This movie has the greatest plot twist in history and introduces so many new characters. The emperor boba fett Yoda lando. Without boba fett we wouldn't have the mandalorian or jango fett.

reviews.content: Went to go see this in theatres for the 40th anniversary and it did not disappoint I would argue that yes it doesn't all look real but for 1980 it is very impressive. reviews.content: Note: this review is based on the 2019 version of the film available on Disney+. There have been many different versions of "The Empire Strikes Back" released through the decades, and the original "Star Wars" trilogy is infamous in the fact that the original theatrical versions of the films are not widely available to the public. With this in mind, I believe that denoting which version of the film that I am watching to write this review should be taken into account. "The Empire Strikes Back" is the least altered of the original movies, with only a few very minor shots, special effects, and continuity changes made to the movie. It is commonly believed that this is because George Lucas had the least amount of involvement in the production of this one. I honestly don't mind any of the changes made to the second film at all: the continuity changes help bring the movie in line with other films in the franchise, and the updated special effects at Cloud City are nowhere near as jarring and annoying as the changes to Mos Eisley in the first movie, or Jabba's Palace in "Return of the Jedi." That all being said, I would still prefer the option from Disney to watch whichever version of the movies that I want to watch. A special release similar to the "Blade Runner" box set would be nice."The Empire Strikes Back" takes place some time after "Star Wars", as our heroes are all in hiding on the remote ice planet of Hoth. Darth Vader (David Prowse/James Earl Jones) is sending probes out to distant star systems to find the hidden Rebel base and to find Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill), who the Emperor (Ian McDiarmid in this version, Clive Revill/Marjorie Eaton in the original) believes will be a powerful asset. After a battle between snow-speeders and AT-AT walkers on Hoth, Luke splits off from Han Solo (Harrison Ford) and Princess Leia (Carrie Fisher) to go to the planet Dagobah, where he will receive further Jedi training from Master Yoda (Frank Oz). Meanwhile, Han, Leia, Chewbacca (Peter Mayhew), and C-3PO (Anthony Daniels) make a daring escape from the Empire through an asteroid field. They eventually wind up in Cloud City, which is governed by an old friend of Han's, the sly Lando Calrissian (Billy Dee Williams).Everything from the original "Star Wars" is improved. The stakes are higher, the plot, pacing, and tone are all slimmed down and tightened. Mark Hamill gives a much better performance this time around, no longer being the annoying and whiny brat that he always seemed to be in the original to me. The single main villain this time, as opposed to having two villains in the first film (Tarkin and Vader), gives the movie a much better narrative focus. Vader is also much more interesting in this movie, too. He was little more than a henchman for Tarkin in the first, but this time his character is given some depth, and he also delivers one of the greatest plot twists in the history of cinema.The special effects in "The Empire Strikes Back" are yet another thing that Lucasfilm beefed up. Compare the Death Star attack in the first movie to the asteroid field scenes in the second. The use of puppets for tauntauns, asteroid monsters, and Yoda all still hold up well today, forty years after the release of the movie. The stop motion effects for the tauntauns are probably the only effects that have aged poorly, but they're actually pretty well obscured by the snowy environments of Hoth, and they're really only employed during long shots anyways.This is a personal favorite, and it's rightly regarded as one of the greatest sequels of all time. Most great sequels still often stand in the shadows of their predecessors. I can only think of three off the top of my head that completely blow the originals out of the water ("Terminator 2: Judgment Day" and "The Dark Knight" being the other two). The entire original "Star Wars" trilogy is worth a watch for any movie fan. I can understand personal arguments for the preference of either of the other films, but one can't deny that "The Empire Strikes Back" is the most well-crafted film in the entire saga. It's quite a shame that both the prequel and sequel trilogies were not able to recapture the magic and cultural influence that the original group of movies did, which set a benchmark for action-adventure blockbuster cinema and inspired generations.

reviews.heading: BEST MOVIE IN THE ORIGINAL TRILOGY

reviews.content:
QUICK REVIEW SEPTEMBER 2020
The 4K remaster is in cinemas and I was surprised how strong the movie is 40 years after its original release. The pure inspiration behind the traditional stop-motion, scale-model, and blue screen special effects, as well as the depth of practical sets, sound effects and score keep this film in the top 5 sci-fi/fantasy cinema experiences even today.
In today's industry of movies made with the option for streaming at home, this movie stands out as something designed ... purely ... for ... the ... big ... screen (and sound system!). Everything is amplified and it is just pure epic ... ness!The darker, more adult story elements that spooked me as a child still hold weight today. The humour holds up as well.Something odd that I noticed; as Han and Lando meet again I thought, hey, that standalone Solo movie actually fits in well here. You know, you don't have all that post-prequel-trilogy-extra-baggage of, "Why doesn't Vader recognise R2D2?" or "Why doesn't older Obi-Wan recognise R2D2?" or "How come ghost Obi-Wan thinks Luke was their only hope?"
I digress.It still packs a wallop today. Lucasfilm still knows how to make the most of the OF (original franchise)!
reviews.heading: The Empire Strikes Back ... Again

reviews.content: This film as well as A New Hope has put me in a very very strange predicament. How exactly does one evaluate a film in which one knows the entire plot a priori, to no fault of the film. As well as a film with astounding visuals at the time, but very poorly aged visuals and shot selection today. Such is my problem with star wars as a franchise. So considering the circumstances, let me shortly say the following.Star Wars is an excellent intellectual property based on an excessively cheesy movie franchise. I feel similarly to the star wars franchise as I do the Marvel cinematic universe. They are a set of fun and entertaining family movies that can make your imagination go absolutely wild. I know I'm not alone in pretending that I was a Jedi or a Superhero when I was young. What the franchise is not is any sort of art film or strong statement about anything. It is pure fun, but perhaps better left in nostalgia than a film to come back to. As the weight of the visual technology fades, it is hard for me to justify that the average storytelling and wonderful soundtrack are enough to carry it.Conclusion: wonderful IP and universe, very cheesy film.
reviews.heading: How do you review a cultural icon?

reviews.content: So much amazing action and beautiful cinematography makes for such an enlightening experience! In The Empire Strikes Back you know who everyone is which is great plus Yoda is introduced! I love this movie the music is soothing, there's romance, more of Darth Vader, and introduces Emperor Palpatine what more can you ask for? A lot to relish and get excited about; it's such a classic gem.
reviews.heading: Excellent movie

reviews.content:
My favorite Star Wars film and my fifth favorite movie of all time.
It does exactly what a sequel should do: Improve upon its predecessor!The pacing is slower but it helps the story and the characters to develop.The tone is a lot darker. Sometimes this can work to the detriment but here it helps the movie.The chemistry between Han and Leia is fantastic! It's charming and funny! The "Nurfherder" and "Lazerbain" lines were stupid but you forget about that scene pretty quickly.The score is superb. The Imperial March is one of the best pieces of music ever conceived.It goes in directions you don't expect. And I'm not just referring to the big twist. I'm also referring to how the movie ends at a low point as well as a cliffhanger.It leaves things up to your imagination. Like Luke's face in the mask. Or the Force, despite it going a little deeper into it.Effects that were impressive for the time are at this point either bad but very charming, or still good.An intimidating villain. This is the movie that turned Darth Vader into one of the best villains ever! In fact, the Empire in its entirety is a lot more threatening.Fantastic performances from everybody.Complex, nuanced characters.Even though Yoda is clearly a puppet he still feels alive. Seeing him as CG in the prequels infuriates me. I do not believe for a minute that he is there.Memorable lines:"I'll see you in hell!"
"I love you." -> "I know."
"No! Do! Or do not! There is no try!"
Out of all the Star Wars movies this one has by far the best script.Intense action. The action also feels a lot more gritty compared to A New Hope.It's super well-shot, especially compared to all the other Star Wars films! This is a movie that really lets you soak in the environment!
Sure, it's got some cheese, some dumb lines, and some things that don't make any sense, but that's to be expected from Star Wars. And because everything else is so good you don't really care.
Even when I was a kid this one was my favorite. I didn't know why at the time. But looking back on it, I can say that it was because the film is darker and slower compared to the others.I'm also happy that out of all the movies in the original trilogy this is the one that George Lucas screwed with the least. I hate that for changing, "You're lucky you don't taste good." to "You're lucky you got out of there." Thank you, George, for once again not thinking something through and taking that enjoyably corny joke and changing it to something completely bland that makes Luke seem less witty. However, I give credit where credit is due: You made cloud city seem a lot less claustrophobic, despite the fact that, much like the CG in all of the prequels, and the CG you just had to shoehorn into A New Hope, the CG looks like garbage!
reviews.heading: My Favorite Star Wars, and my fifth favorite movie!

reviews.content: The first Star Wars was a film about adventure - the wishful desire and the rushing excitement of it. It provided the audiences with a sweeping cinematic experience, as they experienced the galactic adventures alongside their iconic characters: Luke the Hero, Han the Renegade, Leia the Princess, Obi-Wan the Wise One, C-3P0 and RD-D2 the comedic duo. The characters were nothing more than archetypes, but this enhanced the immersive nature of the story, because the audience could see their own traits reflected in each character in a galaxy far far away...The Empire Strikes Back is the definitive sequel to Star Wars because it directly confronts the original's primary theme: Adventure. The Original was a film about desire; to long for more - to look out on the horizon. However, Empire is a film that's not about looking out, but looking in - the film has a stronger focus on the internal, rather than the external. Yoda is quick to remind not only Luke, but the audience, of this fact:"All his life, as he looked away... to the future - to the horizon. Never his mind on where he was - what he was doing! Adventure! (Scoffs) Excitement! (Scoffs) A jedi craves not these things. You are reckless!"And that's what I love about Empire, and that's why it's such a strong sequel - it directly confronts the prior film's ideas. The film dwells on the consequences of someone's narrow-minded pursuit of their wishful desires. Luke is not only burdened with responsibility and leadership, but he will face his ultimate enemy: Darth Vader. But what's so compelling about the two character's conflict is not the external conflict of Man vs Man, but the internal battle. When Luke enters the cave, he confronts his greatest fear. But his greatest fear isn't the man clad in a black cape approaching him, it's when Luke sees his own face in Vader's helmet. He's afraid that he'll follow Vader's path, and that's the internal conflict that propels the training scenes with Yoda.The duel between Luke and Vader is absolute perfection for many reasons: stunning cinematography, choreography and sound design. But those stylistic aspects are nothing without the internal substance. The duel is so enrapturing because of the internal, rather than the external. Luke holds an incredible determination to defeat Vader for many reasons: firstly, to prove that he can be triumphant over the dark side and to overcome his inner conflict. His second motivation however, is contradictory of his first: it is to kill Vader as an act of vengeance for Obi-Wan. This is why Luke chooses to try to kill Vader rather than trying to help him. Ironically, Luke's pursuit to vengeance would ultimately lead him down a path to the dark side - a path which is he so afraid to take, and hence, why he so desperately wants to triumph over Vader. This is why the "I am your Father" moment holds so much impact: Luke wanted to prove that he was different than Vader - to prove that he wouldn't be seduced by the dark side. However, his greatest fear had been realised: the man he so desperately wanted to be different from, is his father; an inextricable link that he must confront.As written above, one of the greatest strengths of Empire are the Characters. In this sequel, the characters are no longer labels or archetypes - they only go by their own name: Luke is no longer the Hero, Han is no longer the Renegade, Leia is no longer the Princess; but each are Luke Skywalker, Han Solo, and Leia Organa. The characters evolve beyond their rigid archetypes into the icons we know and love today. Han's character is shown to have surprising emotional depth, and the same can be said for Leia. Her mask of feistiness that she displayed in the first film is shattered in the sequel, as signs of emotional vulnerability are illuminated. Furthermore, I found the two character's romance to be brilliant, not just because of the chemistry between Ford and Fisher, but also because it brought great humanity to a story that was already abundant in it.The Empire Strikes Back is a phenomenal sequel, as it deals with the prior film's themes head-on: most notably, the theme of adventure. The film displays the consequences of one's wishful pursuit for adventure and tells the audience to focus not on what's out there waiting for them, but to focus on what's waiting inside for them. In addition to this, Empire greatly elevates the archetypal characters into fully-fledged humans; most notably the trio of Luke, Han and Leia. Moreover, the film also dwells on some thought-provoking material, which the prior film lacked in my opinion. What stimulated me intellectually were the intense internal struggles of Luke Skywalker, and his consistent conflict between Light and Dark, Good and Bad. All in all, The Empire Strikes Back is the definitive follow-up to Star Wars.
reviews.heading: The definitive sequel to a modern classic.
