reviews.content: Following the massive success for the first Star Wars film, George Lucas had hoped to become independent from the Hollywood system in choosing to finance the budget from the other two sequels himself. To develop the story for Empire Strikes Back, Lucas brought on sci-fi writer Leah Brackett to write the screenplay. In the first draft, Brackett would have Luke's father appear as a spirit to Luke thus tying into the backstory provided in A New Hope. Upon reading Leah's screenplay, George was less than pleased but before he could meet with her and fix the script, Brackett passed away thus leaving Lucas to write the next draft himself but he brought on Lawrence Kasden to reanalyze the screenplay. Unlike A New Hope, Lucas chose not to direct Empire Strikes Back because he was focused on running Lucasfilm as a business, overseeing the VFX company Industrial Light and Magic, and financing other Lucasfilm projects. George then offered the director's chair to his old film mentor, Irvin Kirschner. Known for more character-driven films like The Eyes of Laura Mars, Kirschner had never directed a blockbuster before and he originally rejected the offer, fearing the sequel wouldn't match the standard of the original film. When he called his agent, though, he later accepted the job at his agent's behest. Shooting for Empire Strikes Back began in Norway in early 1979 where they encountered the worst storm in 50 years with temperatures of -20 degrees and 18 feet of snow. On one occasion, the crew were unable to leave their hotel to shoot a scene of Luke escaping the Wampa cave so Irvin was able to achieve a shot involving Luke's exit of the Wampa cave by opening the hotel's doors and filming Mark Hamill running out into the snow while the crew remained warm inside. When the film opened in June of 1980, it did incredibly well at the box office and with moviegoers, but critics were mixed on the film, but over time, the film has been received far more positively and is now considered by many to be the best out of the entire Star Wars saga.In the annals of moviemaking, no film series has had as much of an impact on me and my love of film as George Lucas' epic sci-fi saga, Star Wars. Much like many other kids of my generation, I grew up thinking, dreaming, watching, and playing Star Wars. I watched the original trilogy on repeat and owned so much Star Wars merchandise at one point in my life that it became an obsession. When I was growing up, the second film in the original Star Wars trilogy, The Empire Strikes Back was never my favorite as I always preferred Return of the Jedi over it but in more recent years after watching the film more times when I even care to count, I began to see the film more for what it was and still is as over 40 years later, Empire Strikes Back is still a fantastic film and one of the few sequels that manage to be even better than their predecessors in terms of story, themes, and characters.The film opens with the Empire searching for the Rebels using probe droids. The Rebel Aillicene has fled to the ice planet Hoth as a result of the Empire's pursuit. While out on petrol, Jedi in training Luke Skywalker is ambushed by a Wampa. Back at Echo Base, Han Solo is worried that Luke hasn't returned so sets out to find him. Meanwhile, Luke is able to escape the Wampa's cave with the use of his lightsaber but soon succumbs to the frigid temperatures. Han eventually recuses Luke and takes him back to the base to recover. The Rebels are soon discovered by an Imperial probe droid and prepare to evacuate the base. The Empire launches an attack against the Rebel base using AT-AT walkers. Han, Leia, C-3PO, and Chewbacca manage to escape the base just in time onboard the Millenium Falcon but their hyperspace is malfunctioning as they are pursued by the Empire and flee into an asteroid field. Meanwhile, Luke and R2-D2 travel to the swamp planet Dagobah and encounters a small green creature who reveals himself to be the Jedi master Yoda. At first, Yoda feels Luke is too old to be trained as a Jedi but finally agrees to train him in the ways of the Force. Now, Luke must learn to master the Force while Leia and Han find themselves in love with one another as the Empire closes in around them.Star Wars: A New Hope has often been discussed to death in terms of the context of the late 70s, either as a political subtext of the Vietnam War, George Lucas' rank as an up-and-coming director alongside the likes of Coppola and Speilberg or even the way how the film shifted Hollywood's focus away from more low-key dramas to massive blockbuster films. Despite all that, it's often overlooked how dynamically The Empire Strikes Back is rooted in the conditions of the early 1980s. There're a lot of reasons for this but the most obvious one is that Return of the Jedi deliberately fled back to the trappings of A New Hope, right down to the choice to restage the Vietnam War with the Ewoks standing in for the Veit Cong. There's also a sense of in which the artistic markers of The Empire Strikes Back is far more subdued than those of A New Hope or even The Last Jedi.When viewed with a modern look, Empire Strikes Back seems to signal the arrival of the 1980s. Much like Terminator 2: Judgment Day or Spider-Man 2, it expands both the scoop and scale of the Star Wars universe but also pushes the saga forward in terms of story and characters. Even looking past the now quintessential unveilings of family ancestry and changing power aspects, The Empire Strikes Back redefined what a Star Wars film could be. It's no longer about steering though the just vagueness of an uncertain future or battling with the spirit of American might. It's instead about trekking through social power resources or finding your place in a vast universe. Much like Aliens, Predator or Die Hard, Empire Strikes Back feels like not only a classic 80s film but also, the first truly great 80s blockbuster.Admittedly, The Empire Strikes Back came out in May of 1980, a time of transition for America. Jimmy Carter was still the president but his grip was failing and in the spring of 1980, a new dawn was coming. The 70s had been a rough time for America as it dealt with the consequences of the Vietnam War and Watergate. It had dealt with an oil panic as well as an economic slowdown. The standard family unit was turned upside down as the rise of the two-income family left many kids somewhat unguarded and the increased devoice rate made it easier to dissolve the traditional nuclear family. It's not surprising that the 1970s saw a boom in the horror film genre that tapped into those fears.Star Wars: A New Hope want against that background with its idea of a used future where things were dirty, grimy, and beat-up and where there is no explanation on how technology works in this galaxy as things just happen with the flick of a switch. This idea, as opposed to a slick-looking future, seemed to connect with audiences in a country that was dealing with the injuring of their own idea of what dreams could be. Even the Darth Star seemed like an apocalyptic level threat, with the capacity to destroy an entire planet. The world for A New Hope appeared to be on the verge of falling apart with industrialized prisons on wheels, trash disposals crushing scrap iron in the depths of an intergalactic weapon of mass destruction as well as a washed-up smuggler and his beat-up ship.In contrast, the world of The Empire Strikes Back looks far more polished and shiny. The opening scene replaces the hot sands of Tatooine with the ice wastelands of Hoth. The industrialized surrounding of the Darth Star has been replaced by the regularly glossier and clearer interiors of Imperial Star Destroyers. There's no sign of an apocalyptic weapon of mass destruction, just the Imperial Fleet doing their business as they always do. Indeed, the opening crawl of The Empire Strikes Back proclaims that the Empire has already welcomed automation, leaving a lot of the Rebel hunting to probe droids. Even Darth Vader went though a redesign between A New Hope and Empire to make his costume look more smooth and polished. The shoulder pads are more noticeable, Vader's center respirator is more complicated, his eyes are black and glossy thus removing the red hue from A New Hope. At one point in the film, the viewer does get to see Vader without his helmet, thus showing he isn't a robot but an actual flesh-and-blood human. This fits perfectly with the massive artistic shift of the Empire within the film as a whole. In a New Hope, the character of Grand Moff Tarkin was portrayed as a commanding persona, having a characteristic figure and speaking with an ice-cold command whereas The Empire Strikes Back introduces us to several Imperial officers who feel like pencil-pushing minsters rather than men who evoke fear into their subordinates. Outside of Vader, Imperial officers seem exchangeable and ubiquitous. Admiral Piett somehow survives until Return of the Jedi mostly by keeping his head low to the ground but few viewers of the films would be able to pick him out of an Imperial line-up.In The Empire Strikes Back, the Empire seems to have become an organization specified by its middle-management. It's a massive and ungainly organization that exists to squeeze the galaxy into submission through the use of force and terror. In A New Hope, the Empire was portrayed as a planet-killing monster whereas Empire Strikes Back depicts them as a more controlled operation as Vader never issues orders to destroy Hoth or Bespin even though he does have the power to do so but rather threatens to bring them both to heel through sheer force. This shift in the characterization of the Empire in The Empire Strikes Back feels very much in tune with what was happening in the 80s as America progressed into the Reaga era. Much like the 70s, the 80s would be seen as a decade of excess and consumerism. This kind of fear was also perfectly captured

reviews.content: The Empire Strikes Back is the definition of a perfect sequel does everything a great sequel does while also making it unique and different from the first one. It expanded the world of Star Wars giving us new planets and new ideas to explore and also made the characters more interesting by adding more layers to them and adding new characters who are also interesting. It also expanded the Star Wars universe more by making the villains more interesting and relatable as well. The action and music as well is step up from the first giving you so much more in this amazing universe. Overall it's not just a perfect sequel but a perfect film as well with nothing wrong about it's perfectly paced, perfectly acted, perfectly written, and just perfect that's really how I describe this movie and it's one of the best of all time. Overall grade= A+

It has it all, great story, space fights, adventure, awesome lightsword fight sequences, drama, comedy and even some romance.It expanded the Star Wars mithology presented in the first movie with such grace, that established a legion of die hard enthusiasts up to this days. reviews.heading: The best of the series

reviews.content: Whenever one of the few good movie sequels comes out, it is (rightfully) held in comparison to this sequel to Star Wars (1977). Not only is it one of, or maybe even the best sequel ever made, but also one of the best movies of all time.Star Wars was a lighthearted adventure, full of memorable characters, groundbreaking special effects and conciously campy plot of a colorful group of heroes fighting an evil Empire led by a Dark Lord and prevailing at the end.The Empire Strikes Back sets itself apart from that right off the bat, when The Empire takes revenge for their loss, utterly crushing the Rebellion in an epic battle on the ice world of Hoth. Following a iconic battle with the Imperial Walkers, the rebels are forced to escape, Han Solo and Princess Leia in one way and Luke in another, hoping to find the legendary Jedi Master Yoda who can complete his training.Yoda himself is one of the main draws to the movie, he is such a fantastic character. Luke goes looking for a great and physically strong warrior, yet instead finds this miniature creature who has no physical skill or weapon provice at all, instead he complements it with his spiritual strength, showing that the force truly stands above such trivial matters. The puppet looks amazing and Frank Oz does a great job voicing him.We are also introduced to a nice twist in which we finds out that Darth Vader is not actually the true main villain, but merely a minion. We always knew there was an Emperor, but when his shadowy hologram appears for the first time, we learn that he uses the force, and that he was the one who converted Vader to the Dark Side in the first place.Then, of course, there is the climax, in which Luke fights Vader, seeking revenge for Ben Kenobi and his father, and in the end learning that Darth is actually his father. It truly stands as one of the great twists in cinematic history and turned the story completely upside down.Overall, the movie maintains the sense of lightheartedness and fun of the original, whilst making it more dark and complex. The character development, special effects and music are all amazing. Director Irvin Kershner truly nailed it in his follow-up to a legendary film.This is how you make a sequel to a movie without doubt! Just make sure you watch the 1980 theatrical cut, as George Lucas came back in later releases and ruined the film, even though he didn't make it.
reviews.heading: One of the best sequels of all time

reviews.content: Excellent, led by Star Wars veteran Paul Hirsch, but it is known that both George Lucas, and his then wife Marcia were also heavily involved in putting the film together. Peter Suschitzky's photography is more conventional and low key in approach than A New Hope, but is particularly effective on the Dagobah scenes in Elstree Studios, and the location scenes in Norway.

2) The John Williams score is flawless

A lot of the dialogue during the 40 minutes on Hoth is incredibly cringey and it also features the infamous brother and sister kissing scene. reviews.heading: Excellent follow-up

reviews.content: "Star Wars V: The Empire Strikes Back" (1980) was the anticipated follow-up to the initial mega-hit blockbuster from 1977. It's an epic, but simplistic space fantasy about an evil empire and the noble souls who dare to fight it. The main cast features Mark Hamill (Luke Skywalker), Harrison Ford (Han Solo), Carrie Fisher (Princess Leia), Billy Dee Williams (Lando Calrissian), Alec Guinness (Obi-Wan Kenobi) and the voice work of James Earl Jones (Darth Vader), Frank Oz (Yoda) and Clive Revill (Emperor).This is an amusing, inventive, iconic space adventure with a stellar cast. While I prefer the adult-oriented space science-fiction of Star Trek, I can't deny that this space fantasy grants you an entertaining two hours with lots of sci-fi action, space ships, a snowy planet, asteroid caves and mysterious swamps. I also appreciate the mind-powers angle. It doesn't hurt that Fisher is in her prime and easy on the eyes, not to mention Ford and Williams are at their charismatic best. Even the more obscure Hamill shines in his boyish youth. Then there's RD-D2, C-3PO and Chewbacca.The film runs 2 hours, 7 minutes.GRADE: B
reviews.heading: Fun, imaginative, iconic space adventure with a kick-axx cast

reviews.content: This film is legendary. Controversial opinion but it's my second favourite in the series. I love the moment when Luke and Leia hear eachother through the force.
reviews.heading: Great movie

reviews.content: I think the real reason The Empire Strikes Back is such a good film is because it was written by Leigh Brackett, not Lawrence Kasdan. I believe all the major story ideas and plot points of Empire came from Brackett's draft and were later adapted, by Kasdan, into the final screenplay. Had Brackett survived and continued working on Empire, it probably would have been even better.My first suspicion that Kasdan was a hack writer came many years ago after I, like everyone else, heard he had written Empire. I immediately checked Kasdan's filmography to see if there were any other notable films I had not yet seen. Unfortunately, the only other poignant movie written by Kasdan was Indiana Jones: Raiders Of The Lost Ark (for which George Lucas wrote the story). Kasdan also wrote the screenplay for ROTJ, and I personally think that ROTJ is both a cheap and poorly written film. ROTJ was my first clue that Kasdan may not have been responsible for the success and quality of Empire.Upon further research into the writing of Empire I eventually found Brackett's name buried in an article somewhere: Researching Brackett I noticed she had co-written the screenplay for "The Big Sleep" (1946) with Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall. I remember watching all the major Bogart films in college and now, upon comparison to Empire, I see major similarities - especially in the romance and drama genres. This is also a big clue.Kasdan was able to skate by for many years without writing anything, allowing him to soak up the admiration for Empire without providing any body of work for comparison (besides ROTJ). Now that Kasdan's name has been plastered all over the media for the Disney Star Wars remakes we can now see that Kasdan has no real writing talent.I am happy to say that I know Lawrence Kasdan is not a good writer.
reviews.heading: Leigh Brackett is what made this movie good, not Lawrence Kasdan.

reviews.content: The story of the rebellion against the Galactic Empire continues with Luke, Leia, Han, Chewie, R2 and 3PO on another blistering ride.The best praise I can give The Empire Strikes Back is that it was the first Star Wars movie to hold my 3 year old daughter's attention for the entire duration, and it's easy to see why as virtually every scene is a new and interesting story.Several great characters are introduced such as Yoda, Lando, Boba Fett, and the Emperor, who add further interest to the overarching story, while the original movies favourites of Han, Chewie, Leia, Luke, Darth Vader, and the droids continue to entertain.There are countless cinematic moments such as the Hoth planet scenes, the epic chemistry between Han and Leia, and virtually everything that happens on Degaba and in the Cloud City. The classic scene with Luke and Vader is so atmospheric and dramatic you will be hard pressed not to find yourself role-playing it with your own children one day.John Williams is the true star of the show as his music fits the emotion of every scene perfectly. I still catch my daughter humming the Imperial March to herself from time to time.Visually it is one of the greatest movies of all time, with groundbreaking (for the time) effects, excellent cinematography, editing, action sequences, puppetry, sets, costumes and battles. Likewise the sound effects are wonderful.The performances include memorable turns from James Earl Jones, Frank Oz, Mark Hamill, Carrie Fisher, Harrison Ford and Anthony Daniels.Some consider it to be superior to the original Star Wars (A New Hope) and they may well have a point. It is darker, more intriguing, delivers an excellent twist, and ends on the edge of a cliff. However, the spectacle didn't awe me on the same level as the original. This is not fault of the sequel, as it simply came second, and much like a junkie chasing their first high I never quite achieved the same feeling.(This review is for the original theatrical release and not the special edition)
reviews.heading: Wars not make one great

reviews.content: First of all, this is not just my all-time favourite sequel but my all-time favourite film. It thoroughly deserves that title because I consider it nothing less than a masterpiece. It takes everything great about the original and simply improves on it, a task many would've seemed to be impossible.With Irvin Kershner taking the reigns of director, from George Lucas, the film goes into a not necessarily darker tone but more mature. With A New Hope being a more light-hearted, but no less iconic, space opera this change puts more focus on the emotions of the characters we have met and, in turn, raises the stakes for heroes, especially Luke who must now face his foe.Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher and Mark Hamill maintain the effortless portrayal of their respective characters from the first film. The introduction of Billy Dee Williams as Lando is simply brilliant as he too fully embodies his role and bounces off Harrison Ford's Han Solo. Another introduction is that of Yoda (operated by Frank Oz) that adds to the mystery of 'The Jedi' and 'The Force' as this character is just overloaded with so much wisdom and is used so well to build Luke's character throughout the film.'Empire' contains possibly one of the most memorable line's in of all cinema; those who have seen this know exactly what I mean. However, it far from relies on this moment as there are a countless number of iconic moments and dialogue.The visual effects of the 1977 release of Star Wars may have been ground-breaking but this film shows how far the industry has come in 3 years. Whether this be the representation of Cloud City, the Walker Assault or even as simple as shots of the Falcon flying. These may seem easy enough to manufacture in 2020 but must have been incredible to see in 1980. I am simply gutted I wasn't able to experience that wonder myself.John Williams again excels at what he does. He is extra-ordinarily consistent in his quality, and not just in this franchise. He truly sends these films into the history books and is one of the many reasons Star Wars, Empire especially, is still so loved today.Empire Strikes Back is truly the heart of this trilogy and is unquestionable in its quality. The Story is unforgettable and the film-making is sublime. I only have two words for those involved in its production: Thank You!
reviews.heading: Simply the Best and Endlessly Rewatchable

reviews.content: I grew up watching Star Wars since I was a kid. It is always full of nostalgia.
reviews.heading: I love this movie. It sure is awesome.

reviews.content: It's just perfect. Its darker and more philosophical. Extremely well directed, acted and great dialogue. IMO Kershner should've been nominated for an oscar for best director. Also best picture.
reviews.heading: Probably the best movie ever made

reviews.content: After destroying the death star, the rebel alliance seek refuge on a remote ice planet called Hoth believing that they will be safe from the Empire. However, it doesn't take long for the evil Darth Vader to discover their whereabouts and he soon sets about destroying their civilisation. Leia, Han Solo, Chewbacca & C3PO all manage to escape on the Millennium Falcon, but when Luke Skywalker gets a message from Ben Kenobi asking him to seek out the Jedi Knight Yoda (who will offer Luke the necessary guidance and training to defeat Darth Vader) Luke naturally obliges...A New Hope was a very good film, but when watching The Empire Strikes Back it always feels like you're watching a slightly more polished version of the original film; it is ever so slightly better in all departments; the pacing was one issue with A New Hope (which in fairness could be attributed to setting the story up) nonetheless The Empire Strikes Back is just that little bit more exciting, energetic and pacey. The Empire Strikes Back also ups the ante with the relationship between Leia and Han Solo (it was simmering in A New Hope, but it's a bit more volatile here). However, it's mostly played for laughs and Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher are both terrific here and are major players in making this picture fun. The whole skit between Yoda and Luke was also enjoyable (as well as being a clearly integral section of the plot).As the villain of the piece Darth Vader shines just that little bit more in this film - he was bad in A New Hope, but here we can really see that he is pure evil (effectively 'offing' members of his crew for failing in their duties). Once again the physical presence of David Prowse and the booming voice of James Earl Jones do a superb job in bringing out the best (or possibly worst) in Darth Vader.Interestingly George Lucas directed A New Hope, but elected to step out of the director's chair and allowed a more experienced director to direct his next film. In my opinion, this was probably a good move as Irvin Kershner does a better job in terms of scale and spectacle. I think in A New Hope Lucas was a bit too intricate and pernickety with the finer details of the story which made A New Hope feel a little elongated.I think Kershner could see Lucas' vision in this film and put this vision to the screen as best as he could and the results clearly speak for themselves.
reviews.heading: The force is stronger

reviews.content:
Why does the Millennium Falcon fly straight towards Darth Vader's star destroyer after leaving Bespin? In all the vastness of space. And what takes so long to turn on the tractor beam? Why didn't they have it ready before instead of waiting till the last second to prepare to turn it on? Like that scene in Spaceballs: "Prepare? What prepare? You're always preparing. Just go!"
Darth Vader should've choked his whole crew after that blunder
reviews.heading: Good movie until the ending

reviews.content: A true masterpiece. in my opinion the best star wars movie.
reviews.heading: Masterpiece

reviews.content: I think every movie should take some inspiration from this. Its compelling characters, its love arcs, its perfect structure. This film builds on sci-fi like very few others will. Its climax isn't about the end of the world. It's about our main characters in danger. This film will always hold a special place in my heart, and will inspire generations to come.
reviews.heading: THIS is cinema

reviews.content:
The Empire Strikes Back expands upon the established world of Star Wars without forgetting what made the first movie so amazing. The effects are just as enthralling as they were in Star Wars (if not more so), as shown in the amazing new worlds that Empire introduces (Hoth, Cloud City, Dagobah), and John Williams once again blows us away with a score that is on par with his work in the previous movie.
The story takes us in a different direction than Star Wars, giving the audience a greater insight into the workings of the Empire and Darth Vader's character. Vader's arc culminates in his iconic confrontation with Luke Skywalker at Cloud City, which ends with possibly the greatest twist in movie history.
Empire's story is more mature than its predecessor, and leading actors have matured and greatly improved as well (props to Mark Hamill, who did about half of his scenes with a puppet and still made them believable). The dialogue is sharp, the camera work is clean, and new iconic characters get to shine in this movie. I especially loved when Yoda gave his explanation of what the force is, increasing the audience's understanding without removing any its mysticism.
Overall, this movie expertly balances pretty much every aspect it should. The acting, the visual set pieces, the sound design, the score, and the story all shine, combining to create a masterpiece of a movie.10/10
reviews.heading: "No, I am your father"

reviews.content: The worst part of the movie were Chewbacca's excessive and excruciating howlings. That, plus the annoying (although less so) R2-D2 noises made the experience less pleasent for no reason (I guess kids love these things?).But beyond that this movie walked the fine line between childish and "serious" in impressive manner. The scripts is way better developing the story, the characters and their relationships, and even connecting all the subplots to the main plot at the end. The dialogue is still not great, but that was to be expected.Plus? We are introduced in much more detail to "The Force", expands the Universe to places beyond "The Rebels" and "The Empire", the score is still awesome and the action gets more diverse and less repetetive (although, it can get a bit boring here and there, it's not even close to the first one). Great sequel in fact.
reviews.heading: Big improvement over the original!

reviews.content: This is the epitome of Star Wars. It is the definite best of the series and does not disappoint. I high recommend this film. The love story will tug at your heart.
reviews.heading: Best Star Wars Ever!!!

reviews.content: One of the best movies in Star Wars is a very interesting movie
reviews.heading: Star Wars Episode 5 Empire Strike Back

reviews.content: The plot twist at the end of this movie is actually really good. It's executed well and sends the Star Wars franchise in an interesting direction. Too bad the rest of this movie was nothing but filler nonsense, lazy setups for future plot lines, and mediocre fight scenes. It's poorly paced and at the end, only three or four scenes end up being important.The entire first act on Hoth is boring and insignificant. The pacing is way too slow considering that this is just the rebels' temporary hideout that is destroyed early on. This entire section of the movie contains so many scenes that are just bizarre in terms of why they're even included. Like when Luke Skywalker gets captured by a yeti for some reason and saves himself using the force despite not even knowing about the force. I honestly don't get why they even decided to drag out the section taking place on Hoth at all. The only reason it exists is to establish that the rebels set up a temporary base and had to leave when the empire attacked it. It would have made sense for that part to happen way earlier in the movie. And speaking of the part where the empire attacks the base on Hoth, the fight scene that takes place here is excruciating. It's dragged out way too much and the action is insanely repetitive. The entire thing is just planes flying around and shooting at big walking machines.The scenes with Luke being trained by Yoda are painfully uninteresting and while this is going on, the other characters are going through some forgettable scenes leading up to one of the dumbest parts of the movie: Han Solo getting captured. He literally just lets the bad guys freeze him in a block of metal, which is one of the laziest possible ways they could have set up this plot line to be resolved in the beginning of the next movie. After that there's some more fighting and the movie ends. That's basically everything notable that happens in this part of the movie. It's completely forgettable and there are very few notable scenes in this entire movie. It's devoid of any personality aside from a few character interactions and the entire thing only exists to deliver one plot twist.
reviews.heading: One good twist following two hours of filler.

reviews.content: Darth Vader is adamant about turning Luke Skywalker to the dark side. Master Yoda trains Luke to become a Jedi Knight while his friends try to fend off the Imperial fleet

This Film can be very enjoyable

reviews.heading: The best one

reviews.content: Not for the life of me do I understand how people think this is better than its predecessor. Yes it has its moments but there is a distinct drop in quality, not least when it comes to the special effects. At times it looks like watching a close up of toy spaceships being moved around on fishing wire.The development of Skywalker is poor throughout these films and is particularly bad here. His progression from outer-galactic farmhand to Jedi Knight is laughably far-fetched and just doesn't seem feasible. His tutelage under Yoda is under-done and the use of 'The Force' as a plot band-aid is tiresome and insincere, a clear example of Lucas' often childish writing.The battle scenes were poor in A New Hope but get even worse in Empire Strikes Back. Very poor choreography and, even for 1980, pretty amateurish special effects. Did people really find the battle between Skywalker and Vader in any way engaging? I honestly just don't get it.There is plenty to admire about this film and it's certainly not the worst sequel ever made but a classic it is surely not.
reviews.heading: May the rose-tinted glasses be with you

reviews.content:
If you were born 1965 or earlier....I can't imagine this being more appealing than other TOP late 70s films such as Network, Serpico, Godfather, Rocky etc.....
Once in a while as an adult I'll watch it purely for Nostalgia my entire massive collection my mother threw out...my figures, my Milenium Falcon...Luke's Glider....planet of the Clouds ships...my Foot tall Vader & Chewbacca, My Star Wars R2-D2 waste basket etc... and to see how much better it looks than something like Infinity Wars..
The father son nonsense...the Jedi Master puppet (total lack of respect Skywalker has for his teachers) this is a Children's basic good vs Evil storyline and that's it. The last one Return..I wish he would have Redone the Return even as a kid Teddy Bear Revolt...Good in you father...Force Force blah blah...very irritating for seeing emperor. If one objectively asks themselves if they were over 12 when these films were released would they LOVE THEM? NO!!!!!
And SHOUT OUT TO JJ....SOME EFFORT IN A NEW STORY LINE?! Your first two star treks and last Star-wars you put a slightly different spin and new actors for pre-existing stories....YOU'RE A TOTAL HACK !
Outside of simply remarkable Special effects and costume pre-CGI era is mind blowing...it was done so well that the prequels which was relatively early CGI (Disappointing as they were story wise- were not impressive special effects wise except the Significantly faster choreographed Jedi fights).

Brilliant film all round.

reviews.heading: Best Star Wars Movie, simple

reviews.content: Public opinion on popular movies has a way of snowballing towards one of two directions. A disappointing movie becomes an unholy dumpster fire and a solid sequel becomes an undisputed masterpiece. The Empire Strikes Back is certainly overrated. It's a great film, as are all the Star Wars movies (the six that count anyway), but Episode V is not a dramatic step up from A New Hope or any of the other films in the saga. The movie has become so overrated that many say it's not just the best Star Wars movie, but the only Star Wars movie that is any good at all. People are dumb. And I want to take the contrarian stance, but let's face facts, The Empire Strikes Back is a perfect sequel to the landmark movie event that was Star Wars. It deepens the mythology, lending George Lucas' world a gravity and psychological weight not seen in the buoyant original. It's also just as quirky and clunky as any other Star Wars film, so let us not rewrite history. TESB is a great film, a great Star Wars film, possibly the best of the six, but not the overwhelming triumph of the series that SO many people claim it to be.A change in director for a Star Wars film is not the world-shifting event many like to portray it as. George Lucas remained the architect of The Empire Strikes Back. Exhausted by the trials of shooting A New Hope, he hired Irvin Kershner to get his vision onto the screen. The result works, contrary to popular sentiment, because the style of the film doesn't deviate too harshly from Lucas' original. There is a movement in the fan community to credit Kershner as some kind of auteur that wrangled the saga's reigns from Lucas and envisioned it in his own way. That's hyperbolic nonsense. Kershner does a good, nay, great job with Lucas' material. He is a reliable professional, but not a genius that saved the series from its creator. It was Lucas, after all, who envisioned this story.The darkness of Empire is also a fan favorite element. There have been volumes of words written on the film's approach to the second-act trope of going darker and more weighty before an eventual triumphal finale. Empire adheres to this structure very well, eschewing a Hero's Journey for a cliffhanger, to-be-continued bummer of an ending. For some reason, this is really profound to lot of fans. Like a revolutionary idea that elevates the film to stratospheric levels. I've never gathered why darker, bad-guy-wins endings are considered any better than heroes-save-the-day endings. Just because they don't happen as often? Darkness is valued more than almost anything when it comes to blockbuster film buffs. Maybe it comes from some deep-seated embarrassment that you like a silly thing like Star Wars in the first place, and a darker film validates your love. "See, it's dark, like a grown-up movie!" I'm comfortable admitting that I prefer Star Wars as the kid-friendly space adventure it is, and while I can appreciate, and actually welcome the darker chapters, I feel no obligation to elevate them as worth "more" as films.That's all to say that Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back is a great movie. A perfect sequel, a terrific middle chapter in a terrific trilogy. However, the push to declare it as the undisputed pinnacle of the entire Star Wars project is frustrating. A New Hope is always going to be the most iconic, the most cherished, the film that will last forever. Revenge of the Sith still bests Empire for dramatic intensity and darkness. And personal tastes must dictate that any of the other movies in the saga could hold favor over it. Yet, The Empire Strikes Back still has some kind of stranglehold on the top spot of Star Wars films. It's the easy consensus pick. You can point to the fact that pesky Gorge is not credited as writer nor director (even though his influence superseded everyone else's), you can identify it's clear "dark" elements as evidence that the movie is "more mature", and you can also just go along with the herd and proclaim it as the best because that's what everyone says. The movie's reception really shouldn't bug me the way it does. I really love The Empire Strikes Back. I think I take issue with its overinflated sense of greatness because it comes at the expense of the other five films. Each one of George Lucas' six movies has a claim as someone's favorite. They are all of a very high level of blockbuster filmmaking. I want to give the others the praise they also deserve.88/100
reviews.heading: Star Wars' Perfectly Great Sequel Deserves a Little Less Praise.

reviews.content: I think this movie is amusing and decent. With its interesting storyline, good characters, a surprise plot twist towards the end, and so much more are sure to keep you entertained. I don't like the scene when Han Solo gets frozen. But all in all, I recommend you give this a try.
reviews.heading: Decent

reviews.content: This film made such an impression on a ten year old boy that I, watching it forty years later for just the second time, still know the details of the story, characters and scenes by heart.Rebels hiding on an icy planet are discovered and overrun by Darth Vader, storm troopers and sophisticated machinery. The prize that eludes their grasp is not so much the rebel forces but a young man, Luke Skywalker, who has the potential to become a great leader, visionary and warrior; a jedi knight. While Skywalker trains to be a jedi his friends are captured and used as bait to lure him into a trap where he will be forced to choose whether he wants to join Vader's forces or die.The secret sauce of The Empire Strikes Back and what makes it infinitely better than Star Trek, is the jedi knight philosophy expressed by its master practitioner Yoda. It simply radiates wisdom and truth and resonates in our hearts. "Do or do not," Yoda says "there is no try." He warns against anger, fear and aggression which flow easy and are seductive. It is much better to ally yourself with the "force" and the life energy that surrounds and binds us. The romance between the characters of Han Solo and Princess Leia, and the acting of Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher that bring it to life, also makes a sad sack of the Star Trek franchise. Unfortunately, the romance is unbalanced and macho oriented, as well as PG rated. Still, it is more romance than a hundred Star Trek episodes put together. Mark Hamill is a bad actor who, deservedly, drifts into the shadows and has no more successful roles to play.While the Empire Strikes Back is a wonderful film, it does not occupy the exalted place in my mind and heart as it did 40 years ago. It is the difference too, between boy and man. These days I desire more depth in beauty and wisdom, in writing and cinematography, than this somewhat simple film achieves. Still, there is some magic here among the vanilla.
reviews.heading: 40th Anniversary

reviews.content: It's another great job here, great script, incredible visual effects, fantastic soundtrack and good performances. Another great Star Wars movie.Film seen on April 20, 2020
reviews.heading: Nice

reviews.content: After the resounding success of A New Hope, George Lucas became one of the most admired filmmakers and most successful film industry. As the director got the profits from the previous film, he was brave and put much of the money earned in the 1977 film, the production of The Empire Strikes Back. And here he was able to make an even better job. Amplifying all we had shown earlier and presenting new facts of great importance for the entire series of films in cinema, The Empire Strikes Back, even without a beginning and an end, is regarded by most fans as the best of all movies.Being the second film released and the fifth in chronological order, as George Lucas was the executive producer to focus better and have full control of the plot, and gave the synopsis for the screenwriters Leigh Brackett and Lawrence Kasdan could develop the plot. To not get overwhelmed, as before, Lucas entrusted the direction of the long Irvin Kershner, who happily held a job and raised even more irreproachable quality of the saga, confirming its success.It is a critical period for the Rebel forces. The adventure continues in this "Star Wars" sequel. Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill), Han Solo (Harrison Ford), Princess Leia (Carrie Fisher) and Chewbacca (Peter Mayhew) face attack by the Imperial forces and its AT-AT walkers on the ice planet Hoth. While Han and Leia escape in the Millennium Falcon, Luke travels to Dagobah in search of Yoda. Only with the Jedi master's help will Luke survive when the dark side of the Force beckons him into the ultimate duel with Darth Vader (David Prowse).Mark Hamill returns to play Luke Skywalker and continues to play well the hero challenging, courageous and with enormous potential for the "Force". The actor shows the determination of the young man trying to become a Jedi, and seeks to defend his friends from the evil forces at any cost. Curious fact is that due to a serious accident of the actor just before the start of filming, which meant that he spent several surgeries and his face stayed a little different, George Lucas had to modify the beginning of the story, making Luke was attacked by a monster and had his face disfigured and rebuilt plastically.Harrison Ford back as Han Solo. Between the first and this second film, Ford has also been involved in classic praised Apocalypse Now (1979) Master Francis Ford Coppola. Carrie Fisher also back as Princess Leia Organa and earns a highlight even greater following. She empathizes with Ford, despite not knowing if you really want to be with Han or Luke. The cast is so mingled that the chemistry of the actress works well with both. Peter Mayhew as Chewbacca, Anthony Daniels as C-3PO, Kenny Baker as R2-D2 also return. Who appears well is Billy Dee Williams as Lando Calrissian. Your participation and where you live is fundamental to the conduct of the climax of the plot. The Merchant of gas that can be seen at first glance, as a traitor to our protagonists, shows the course of the plot, that their participation is much more thorough. David Prowse with the body and James Earl Jones as Darth Vader voice still leaving threatening. His cruelty appears, for example, when you kill without hesitation a commander who failed a mission. We also see the Emperor Cos Palpatine (voiced by Clive Revill), which dictates the rules for Darth Vader and clarifies its importance only because the villain fear him.No wonder that this is regarded as the main movie of the saga. Is it that important and memorable events that generate consequences in this and the other films occur. Without "The Empire Strikes Back", we can say that the series would not have the same impact today in the minds of moviegoers. Among the main events is the fact that it was here that we hear so famous and world renowned Imperial March, Darth Vader is also seen as the authentic ruthless villain and not just as the commander of the imperial troops, the dear Master Yoda first appears emerging in more depth in philosophy Jedi when he starts training Luke to have mastery of the "Force" and not be susceptible to its "dark side." Appointed as an extremely powerful in the previous film, we were surprised to see an old, softly speaking in funny rhymes and appears harmless but hides within itself a fascinating inner peace. Seeing him not imagine how powerful it is, but anyone who has seen the scanned version of Yoda in "Attack of the Clones" and "Revenge of the Sith" knows what he is capable; see the progress of the relationship and Solo Read, which at first was full of taunts with not wanting to reveal what they felt for each other and then at a crucial moment for him, end up revealing their feelings for one another, a kiss in the next episode would be revealed as "Incestuous"; see the tanks AT-AT. also arise Boba Fett and Lando Calrissian, is the first lightsaber showdown between Luke and Darth Vader, and still have the bombshell revelation that would shake the foundations of science fiction, narrowing the list of enemies and then would have a decisive role in the final Episode VI.George Lucas and his creative team, do not fall into temptation to sin by exaggeration and knew dosing masterfully adventure, action, romance, and science fiction. In the scenarios, the art direction of the trio Leslie Dilley, Harry Lange and Alan Tomkins, nominated for an Oscar for the work along with photography Peter Suschitzky worked precisely with a much wider variation of environments. If at first were introduced to the desert climate and abandonment of Tatooine, beyond the city, here George Lucas presents us with glaciers on the planet Hoth, meteor shower, the huge and well developed where Lando Calrissian and his people live in the City the Clouds, and swampy and gloomy planet Dagobah where Yoda. Without doubt, the new scenarios and photography from white snow to the darker tones of the final climax in Cloud City and Vader's ship, beyond the synopsis of the story itself that keeps the bad guys winning almost all the time, made this the darkest film of the series. Here, as the title suggests, nothing was easy for the Rebels.The special effects are even better than the first film. At the Battle of Hoth, for example, when the AT-AT appears, leave the audience puzzled. Animated in stop-motion with false (which never sounds fake) leave early in the film the feeling that we were facing a great movie. Following the persecution of the Millennium by the rain among asteroid, is very well done. The sequences in Cloud City, including the final climax, are tense, exciting and full of adrenaline. There are still scenes in the nave of Darth Vader and exciting and revealing fight between the villain and Luke. The battles are well choreographed and more realistic than before.The issue remains the same language for the entire series. Paul Hirsch and Marcia Lucas work giving an impressive agility and speed to chase scenes and the ships and the fight scenes especially. The transitions that give an atmosphere fades over TV series remains. John Williams returns once again in the composition of the soundtrack, so keeping track of signs and worshiped still presenting the Imperial March with several clever variations during the long. Again the track is in perfect harmony with the sound, every sound working independently without ever seeming contrived. No wonder that the sound along with the special effects have taken the Oscar deserved.The direction of Irvin Keshner takes us inside asteroids and planets around with incredible realism. Besides these scenes are worthy of applause battle on Hoth with AT-ATs and all sequences of intense action of this battle, the escape of the Millenium by asteroids, and the fight scenes and character development. specially the scene of the great revelation of Darth Vader to Luke is highly valued by management. After an intense lightsaber duel, the two characters on the edge of an abyss, discuss until Vader, filmed from the ground up to enhance the feeling of power, says the famous phrase, leaving Luke and all the spectators in shock. The close in the face of Luke is also striking.It is curious to see, looking at all the movies, the perfect symmetry created by George Lucas from "The Empire Strikes Back" and "Attack of the Clones," In the two secondary reinforces the narrative construction of the personality of the main hero (Luke in training "Empire", and the dating of Anakin in "Clones"), and a fantastic scene including a dueling saber light-end. Not to mention the most important: a hand severed works representing the change in the two films.Darker, more creative and more balanced than the previous, Irvin Keshner George Lucas and surprise the viewer and further expands the saga idolatry, leaving everyone looking forward to the last episode of the saga, concluding all the points raised. A major landmark of science fiction, which only increased the number of followers of Luke Skywalker and his warring parties. It is, along with "Revenge of the Sith", a milestone in the franchise.

reviews.content: It seems like in every trilogy of films, there is always one who shines more than the others. In the original trilogy of "star wars", "The Empire Strikes Back" is the one who shines most then the others. I personally don't know why, maybe it's because of a particular scene in the film? (No, I am your father). Or maybe because it shows that the heroes not always win and suffer a lot? Or maybe because of the charming look of Lando Calrissian (Billy Dee Williams)? Whatever it is, you can't ignore that this film is one of "Star wars" top films and perfect installments of all time.
reviews.heading: The more known from the trilogy 8/10

reviews.content: The Empire Strikes Back is the best film in the original Star Wars trilogy. It has all the great qualities that the original Star Wars has: great effects (at the time of its release), appealing characters, and lots of spellbinding action. It also has eliminated some of the problems that plagued the first: the storyline is tighter, and goes much deeper into character development. The performances are terrific, especially by Harrison Ford as Han Solo, and Billy Dee Williams as Lando Calrissian. George Lucas has also remembered to include a spellbinding battle sequence with the snowspeeder sequence near the beginning of the film. The conclusion, with a lightsaber duel between Darth Vader and Luke Skywalker, is truly one of the most suspenseful and dramatic scenes in the entire series. This is a truly wondrous film, and serves as a constant reminder that just because a movie is expensive and a blockbuster doesn't mean that it has to be shallow and two dimensional. This film will undoubtedly entertain viewers of all ages from start to finish.
reviews.heading: Excellent

reviews.content: Luke, Han and Leia find themselves waging war against the Empire, along the way they meet the Emperor, Lando, Yoda and find out Luke's hereditary tie to a certain Darth Vader. Again as I said in my review for a New Hope, film criticism from me is practically irrelevant since I love the original 3 movies. The Empire Strikes Back is still one of the most shocking film experiences of my life, mainly in how it ended, in which the good guys lost, Darth Vader was Luke's father and it ended on such a somber note. It also led to extreme debate as to where they would go from here and many kids at the lunch table wondered how this twist came to be. I still stand by A New Hope being my personal favorite, but this is a better overall film, the snow walkers in particular are still breathtaking and Cloud City while not as spectacular in 1980, still holds up really well. At the time this was out of this world and I left the theater crushed at the film's finale, but eagerly anticipating Star Wars 3.**** Out Of 4-(Excellent)

reviews.content: That's what I called this when I was too small to reach the movies in my house. My poor mother had to decipher that description.Just as important as A New Hope was to movies, Empire Strikes Back is to sequels. And why? Because Lucas paid for this himself. No one has ever been in his position before. To make huge movies that are financed by the creator. No studio would ever allow a movie like this, it took risks: It's not a rehash, its darker, a realistic puppet was a serious main character and a lot of the story is left in the air.But while this movie is darker than it's predecessor it's not a dark movie, its just darker. People seem to forget that. It's a more serious story but it's still able to maintain the fun feel of 4. It also continues the speed from 4 as well. Instead of getting in huge fights they are just small scuffles. This doesn't feel for a second that it's trying to outdo the original. The story and the characters are expanded and deepened.Yoda was a huge risk, it's hard for us to think of a puppet not being taken seriously, but no one had ever attempted to make a life like puppet before. And sequels weren't a sure cash in either. In order for this movie to break even it had to be the most successful sequel of all time. It's these things that Lucas gave us. He not only knows how to tell a story and make a great movie but he takes risks to do it at the same time. He did this his whole career. If this movie failed not only was Star Wars dead but so was Lucas' career. That'll motivate you.My favorite SW set is in this, the carbon freezing chamber. I don't know if it's the steam, the orange light or the vastness but I love this room. Everyone looks cool here. Especially the Stormtroopers, their white really illuminates the orange well. And you get Vader and Boba in here too.The snow troopers are very cool. I can't figure out if I like them or the Episode 3 clones best.Lando is a great addition because he's the Han that could have been. And Lando gets crap for being bad but he really does make the best call. He appeases Vader to save his life while still giving himself the freedom to save Han in the end. And he hasn't seen Han in years maybe he's become a real , the last time he saw him he was a smuggler after all. And Billy Dee is great, I don't know if anyone is as effortlessly smooth as this guy.3P0 in pieces is a great addition that provides endless jokes.I love Han's love story with Leah because she's given him no indication that she's interested. And he acts like they have this dating history. But he is right because she does want him.And the best part of the movie: Yoda/training. Not only is Yoda the most powerful Jedi of all but you hang on his every word of wisdom. Lines repeated for my entire life. I have always loved the fact that the most powerful Jedi was the smallest. There's just something about that idea that really gets me.And there's really something to be said for the fact that Yoda is not actually real. We all know that Frank Oz did the voice and puppeteered Yoda but the fact that Yoda is not actually real really helps to make his character real. it's not necessarily Frank Oz as Yoda, what you see is the little green puppet as Yoda. There aren't pictures of him at studio 54 or news of him getting married. Yoda is Yoda. when he is not being the puppet on screen he doesn't exist which really helps to his reality.The biggest complaint since Lucas finished the saga was that "I am your father," is now not a surprise any more. Which is true, you do know, but watching them in order you'll probably be surprised that Anakin turns to the dark side. And it might be a surprise that Vader tells Luke this because as far as we know Vader doesn't know who Luke is. He doesn't even know that he has a kid. And we think that Anakin is dead. I don't know... Only time will tell with people who watch these in episode order

reviews.content: I know I'm going to get a lot of hate for this, but, to me, I found Empire to be the, shall we say, least appealing of the trilogy. I know that this sounds bad, but hear me out before you judge me; I have an explanation. I know that most people consider Empire to be the best in the series, but I always found it to be the, for lack of a better phrasing, least appealing. Better than the spinoffs (Solo and Rogue One), which I mostly found to be unnecessary cash-grabs, but still last place in the nine movie lineup. I still love this movie, but there were some key factors that kept it in the lowest position.The biggest issue I had with it is that it had a massive amount of exposition. Don't get me wrong, the battle on Hoth was awesome, so was the fight between Luke and Vader, but everything else in the middle was pretty much a bunch of data dumping, where Luke is learning about the Force, and Han and Leia's relationship is developing while they hide and try to repair the Millennium Falcon. And while I do think that things like world building, character growth, and relationship development are important, when your story is primarily that, it's going to suffer in my opinion.Now, as a kid, I had severe ADHD and a very short attention span, so all the stuff in between the exciting action sequences made it very hard for the movie to hold my interest. For me it was like: What's happening with Luke? Oh, he's still learning about the Force. Ok, what's happening with Han and Leia? Oh, they're still hiding and fixing the Falcon while getting closer. What's happening with Vader? Oh, he's still looking for the Falcon. Ok, lets get back to Luke. Oh, he's still learning about the Force. Rinse and repeat for again and again for over an hour. For a kid like me with a very sort attention span, it was very hard for all this to hold my interest. And sure, they had little tidbits like the giant asteroid worm, but it wasn't enough to hold my attention for long. There was also the cliffhanger ending regarding Han's fate, which my childhood self did not appreciate and was very upset about. Even what was arguably the greatest movie twist in history left no impact on me thanks to my own father, who told me that Darth Vader was Luke's father back when I watched A New Hope for the first time; something I will never forgive him for.Now that I'm older, I definitely have a deeper appreciation and understanding for this movie than I did as a kid, and scenes that I once considered to be boring I now find much more appealing, but the damage was done from numerous re-watches over the years from when I was a kid. So yeah, this is a ranking based a bit on circumstances, but unfortunately that's where it stands. Still a great movie that everyone should see.
reviews.heading: A unique point of view.

reviews.content:
For a generation that grew up in the 80s and 90s, here is the nightmare of childhood and the emotional scar upon the life of many a middle aged adult. The gulf between good and bad, the black and white of youth and innocence has been riped apart in a moment of time and all that is left are the shades of grey. "You killed my father" shouts Luke as he battles Darth Vader "no Luke Skywalker" he replies "I am your Father" So the enemy is not with out, but within.The Empire Strikes Back is the second film in what will probably, since Disney has no intention of slowing down, become the longest running serial in film history. Serial here is the key world, not that Star Wars was originally coincided as such by it's director, although Lucas had his hopes and lots of ideas on paper. The original film was thought to be a risky one off or so the studio thought. Only a hint towards the end of the production that success and a sequel could be at hand saved Darth Vader from being blown up like a firework by the Millennium Falcon. Lucas might have hoped that Star Wars would be such a success that he would be given a chance to make another but to keep making them and to make nothing else was beyond even his imagination.The concept behind Star Wars, how it worked in Lucas' own imagination, is that Star Wars would be rather like a Flash Gordon or Buck Rogers serial. These were made of a number of individual episodes about 20 minuets long with each one ending with a cliff hanger and starting with a miraculous escape. The plotting was sometimes so desperately week the show just about managed to scrape along from one end to another. They were cheap to produce ( although Flash Gorden was the most expensive of them all) and aimed at young children and the Saturday morning picture show. They were made quickly with out to much thought and with sets and music borrowed from other films. Put together by people who were ether glad of the work or would have wished themselves else where. They where rich in corn and low in production vales, totally lacking in pretension and made on the the understanding that every thing in it was disposable and forgettable. Of course no child of any age has ever forgotten a single moment of every episode and certainly made an impression on Lucas. The original Star Wars film was only pretending to be a weekly episode some where in the middle, (episode 4 actually) in a run of films. So that at the start you are immediately thrown into the action. What has come before is related on the now very famous script that scrawls sharply away from the picture frame just as it did at the start of each successive episode of Flash Gorden. the screen wipes and the general air of pulp fiction in Star Wars comes from the serials as well. Like many American film makers of his generation, Lucas was creating a future world by reliving his past.But The Empire Strikes Back really is a midway episode. Dropping you directly into the action with the attack on the ice planet. our band of heroes divide into two groups and take two separate story ark's to Dagobah and the cloud city, allowing the film to play off one against the other and introduce new characters in each story line, before winding back them back together for the finale at which point the film oddly just comes to a stop, with every one backed away from the camera and looking out of the window, with out even a cliff hanger ending, the only unresolved situation is having Han Solo encased in carbon with his fate unknown. Perhaps Lucas just lost his nerve about copying the old serials but couldn't work the story up a dramatic full stop, so things just hang in the air and then the titles role
The Empire Strikes back has some brilliant and ground braking special effects we are still in a an age before computer generated imagery every thing is optical and physical including a stunning chase through a asteroid field. We follow the path of the Millennium Falcon between objects that have their own independent trajectory and bounce off each other. We learn the advantage of have regular service checks on your vehicle and the benefits of having every space craft made from the same airfix parts We are also introduced to new characters including a smooth and swishy Lando Calrissian, Muppet sage Yoda engaging in Hollywood's life long flirtation with Eastern philosophy and mysticism. A menacing villain in the Emperor played by Marjorie Eaton and voiced by Clive Revill (always good to hear the English actor on repeat viewings). The film benefits from not having the burden of a beginning or an ending and with nothing weighing on either side the film just shoots along. Neither Lucas nor his writers could think up an ending for The Return of the Jedi that was not just a slight rehash of the first film and from then on it would hugs and kisses at the end of every adventure. So perhaps it is an advantage that this film just comes to a stop.The reason why The Empire Strikes Back story flows concisely and logically could be because Lucas has taken a back seat to the rough trade of direction to concentrate on co-production. handing the reins over to Irvin Kershner a solid talented professional but not to original or individual a director. Lucas turned to professionals again for the script. Employing Lawrence Kasdan who would go on to work on Raiders of the Lost Ark and it's interesting to note that Leigh Brackett wrote an early draft. She goes back a long way and was greatly admired and often used by Howard Harks, who thought her pulp detective fiction (his favorite reading matter) was amongst the finest, he asked her to screen write the screenplay for The Big Sleep. Asking professionals to work with him on the script may explain why this episode feels the most mature, there are no Ewoks, no Ja Ja Binks here thank you very much. Leigh Brackett died in 1978 and not much if any of her work remains in the finished film but she would have recognized the type of dialog runing between Solo and the princess. It was first pioneered by Hawks in screw ball comedies during the thirties in films like Brining up Baby where it is noted by a pompous psychiatrist that " the love impulse in men very frequently reveals itself in terms of conflict" Lucas really was borrowing widely from everything he loved about the cinema of the past.Because of a driving accident just before filming started Mark Hamill's very visible facial scars needed to be explained in the plot, so the film starts with a mini adventure where Han Solo has to find Luke Skywalker who has been lost in the frozen landscape, before nights falls and the temperature drops. This intimate drama was concocted on the spot and yet look at how useful it is at underling the relationship of the characters have with each other right where it is needed at the start of the film. Han is reckless, fool hardy but all so decisive and focused. He is the first to realize that Luke is absent and he is prepared to risk everything to protect his Friend and because something needs to be happening before Solo can realize Lucas is missing, we see Solo and Leia constantly bickering in Howard Hawks style which continues on even as everything collapses around them. Everybody in the writing team is on the ball here and a unexpected necessity is turned in an asset for the production.John Williams provides another score for the film, the quality of the music is as high as the first and you might seamlessly travel from one to the other with out knowing you have crossed a threshold. William's score has been highly praised but I think that something is missing. William score for the original film has some wonderful small delicate wistful moments, as when Luke is contemplating his future while watching the suns of Tatooine go down, there is the wonderful cantina band music and that slightly off center rhythmic tic that is played as Han and Luke prepare for the TIE fighter attack. All of which is evidence of William's love of Stravinsky, Mahler and Prokofiev among others. As good as the music is in The Empire Strikes Back there is nothing quite as diverse as that in it's score. But it does have The Imperial March and the The Imperial March is ace. It was a long time before I realized that Williams composed it for the second film. It's hard to imagine that it was ever absent from the saga. It is without doubt the most the additive tune ever put to film. Start playing it in your head now! And see if you can stop from repeating the tune again and again, louder and louder until your lips start to move and your head bops from side to side. If you can manage that without making a fool of your self then you are no Star Wars fan.The most curious aspect of the film is Lucas' decision to had over the direction to somebody else and to concentrate on the production side. He felt that trying to do both would to difficult so he chose to produce. In no way was he handing over the film for somebody else to make as a director. As the film's producer he had total control over every aspect of the project to make sure it fitted his vision. By choosing not to be the director he didn't have to deal with an irreverence that was getting in the way with what he wanted , the actors. If technology did not allow him to do away with human beings, then at lease there must be a way of making a film with having to discuss acting with them.Eventually that technological dream would come true.
reviews.heading: the love impulse very frequently reveals itself in terms of conflict

reviews.content: After so many years of postponing I finally decided to watch all the Star Wars movies. Since there are different ways to watch it I'm going for the chronological order and not the release date order, that just makes more sense to me. Maybe I watched a couple movies when I was young, I probably did, but I don't remember anything about it so to me it's all new and maybe one day I will understand the whole hype about the Star Wars saga. After watching The Phantom Menace, Attack Of The Clones and Revenge Of The Sith, Solo: A Star Wars Story, Rogue One, and A New Hope it's now time for The Empire Strikes Back. I thought A New Hope was the weakest one, okay it's the oldest one and so the special effects are not of the same level as more recent ones but the truth is that the later ones are just of better quality in every domain. the Empire Strikes Back was already a bit better but still not of the same quality as the others. I probably watched it as a kid and gave up after that as it's just not that good. I don't know why this one gets such a high rating, it's definitely not better than any of the previous titles mentioned. I agree that the used special effects at that time might have looked good for 1980 but still it doesn't make it better. For that the story and the acting were just not of the same quality. By watching the saga in chronological order you appreciate every movie better than in order by release date. It's just a better way to watch the whole saga, it's much easier to follow and for somebody new to it like me it's just much more appealing.The Star Wars saga is great because of the different characters, races of aliens, and the different spaceships and weapons, for that I just love it. I can't wait to watch the next one, will probably binge watch the eleven movies and will probably squeeze The Mandalorian between it, as long as the chronological order is respected. This was the seventh movie of eleven in barely 72 hours for me, next one today will be Return of the Jedi in the hope the quality still continues to improve, looking forward to it.

reviews.content: Compared with current works, this film must be far from special effects. However, powerful special effects may not be able to attract audiences. I think this work is more narrative than its special effects. As a science fiction film at the time, It is very commendable to use a delicate processing method instead of just staying on the display of special effects.
reviews.heading: Very perfect sci-fi movie

reviews.content: I love it as well as my life,though I'm a young fan of Star Wars.
reviews.heading: An excellent movie

reviews.content: Plot wise... well, it's full of holes, like every Star Wars movie. Full of ridiculous "how convenient" moments. Full of inconsistencies with the previous movie. And still awful awful dialogue that's just not how people speak to each other.But, groundbreaking special effects. Stunning cinematography. The whole thing is just so beautiful to look at, especially the stuff in the snow. And, it's a wee bit dark, with an unresolved ending... that was pretty controversial at the time (now we tend to expect it in a sequel). Even though the middle section goes rather slow, it's spellbinding in its tension.To be clear, I'm talking about the original version here. The Special Edition did improve some bits, but ruined others by looking jarringly out of place. Watch the original if you can.
reviews.heading: Not as good as everyone claims

reviews.content: Empire Strikes Back delivers a larger scale, more mature sequel that ticks every box. It's darker but still a lot of fun, it's upped the scale and quality of everything it delivers. Planets like Hoth, Dagobah and Bespin have stuck in fans' memories ever since. The main cast all return, just as good as the first time we met them, this time joined by Lando Calrissian, the smoothest man alive, and Jedi Master Yoda who I'm sure needs no introduction. On the villains front, Darth Vader is joined by Boba Fett - a brutally effective bounty hunter of few words.It's a cool cast, spread out across a large galaxy that really feels like the perfect setting for the epic space opera. The twists keep coming, now well known by pretty much everyone but for a new viewer entirely unfamiliar with them they were absolutely groundbreaking. The action's stepped up since the original - Skywalker vs Vader putting the last film's lacklustre lightsabre duel to shame. The music's as beautiful as ever.The original trilogy are all highly enjoyable films but Episode V has the reputation as the best of them and it's entirely possible that might well be the truth.
reviews.heading: A well earned reputation

reviews.content: The sequel of a masterpiece classic, is hard to top its predecessor but somehow it manage to did that. With better plot and story, the story progession and more characters insight. This sequel is no doubt the best in the trilogy.
reviews.heading: Continue the story of its predecessor.

reviews.content: You have to admire Darth Wader in this masterpiece ."You have failed me for the last time"
reviews.heading: Best Star Wars movie of all

reviews.content: My hands-down favorite of the original Star Wars trilogy. The dark side has started seeking their revenge after the destruction of the Death Star and Luke trains to become the Jedi master that his father once was.Enjoyed the higher budget compared to the first Star Wars movie and how the Empire actually wins a few battles this time. Makes the whole "galactic war" seem more real.5/5. I'm sure the other fanboys have more extensive movie reviews for those who are interested.
reviews.heading: Instant Fav -- best of the OG trilogy

reviews.content: This movie made Darth Vader one the most iconic evil guy ever. Rewatching it after Han's Solo movie I was happy to see what happened to Lando. The battles were cool and led to many videogames. Han's romance with Leia had nice progress. Yoda was awesome as a teacher. I would prefer just a better training to Luke. It felt rushed and the results were bad because of it. A great movie anyway that makes you want to see how the trilogy will end. If the purpose was to make the heroes seem in a very bad situation with no hope of winning it succeeded its course. For some reason I enjoyed New Hope more. Maybe I don't like bad guys winning idk

reviews.content:
This movie is awesome man
It's funny, action packed and has a great soundtrack
reviews.heading: This movie rocks

reviews.content: Empire Strikes Back is my favorite film of all time. It is a masterclass of an adventure film that also cements itself as being a mature re-evaluation of good and evil. Though some effects do not hold up perfectly, there are timeless sets and effects used in this gorgeous film to make for some of the greatest world building of all time. Empire offers some of the greatest heroes and villains of any film, making for some of the most interesting confrontations of any adventure film. This film is by far the greatest sequel ever made and my personal favorite film of all time.

reviews.content: This film is just pure awesome, for kids, adults, and everyone in between.Anyone can watch it and get something out of it; for the kids it's the cool worlds and weird-looking creatures, for teens, it's all the cool explosions and action scenes, and adults can enjoy all the character development and darker themes this movie has to offer.This really is a magical movie.
reviews.heading: Possibly the Greatest Sequel in Cinema History

reviews.content: This is an example of how to not only do a perfect sequel, but a perfect sci-fi movie in general.
reviews.heading: Greatest Star Wars movie

reviews.content: I've always been a huge Star Wars fan for as long as I can remember. I was always invested in the world and the characters and the story. I can definitely say as a Star Wars fan this is the best movie of the franchise. Darth Vader is as memorable as ever, including that dramatic jaw dropping moment when he tells Luke he is his father, leading it to be one of cinema's most memorable moments and probably my favorite movie moment! The movie opens up with the planet Hoth and an assault on the rebels, marking yet another marvel of cinema. This movie is my favorite because it's got the most memorable quotes, characters from Darth Vader to Luke Skywalker to the introduction of Yoda and Lando, and incredible cinematic moments that are still remembered and awed at to this very day!
reviews.heading: My All Time Favorite Movie!

reviews.content: A surprise new director at the helm Irvin Kershner, who had previously not directed a really well known film, totally delivered with this incredible (looking) sequel to 'Star Wars'. When I was a teenager, i was gratefully exposed to possibly the finest special effects (for it's time) in cinema history. The advantage of sequels is that all the characters have been previously introduced and so you are straight into the action, on a thrill ride (to outta space and beyond). The musical score was brilliant and most effective, when coupled with an already iconic baddie 'Darth Vader'. The general feeling from the 'Star Wars' faithful, is 'Episode V' is the very best and I totally agree. You can forget the pure crud, they release today under the same banner as 'The Empire Strikes Back' was never, ever bettered.
reviews.heading: Takes it all up to the next level.

The middle film of the Star Wars TRILOGY!
